column1: 9546,"[:en]5 ideal destinations for summer in Vietnam[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: Wanna run away from the heat of crowded city ? Why not paying for a visit to top 5 ideal destinations for summer in Vietnam ?
1. Ha Long Bay

If you plan to visit Vietnam and staying in the North of Vietnam for some days, you should not miss Ha Long Bay - a UNESCO World Heritage and a popular travel destination in the summer. Just simply relax on a cruise, visit cool caves included in cruise itinerary or simply swim in the awesome water of Halong Bay, your summer will become more memorable than ever.

Ha Long is famous for its timeless beauty created by three major elements consisting of limestone, water and sky. With 1969 tall islands full of the thick jungle vegetation rising from the ocean and approximately 1,553 square kilometers in size, it possesses the valued features of sceneries, geo-diversity, biodiversity, culture-history, travelling and resort, which captured the interest of many tourists for ages.

The thing that makes many of you surprised is that the limestone you see formed for over 500 million years. Besides, this site named Ha Long Bay leads people to a lot of ideas about its derivation, and actually, it has its own legendary stories.
2. Nha Trang

Nha Trang is glorified as the most beautiful beach in Vietnam. It makes you fall in love at the first time you’ve been in this city. Toursits can enjoy the beautiful beach with fine and clean sand, clear ocean water with mild temperatures in this summer. It is popular for some resorts such as Vinpearl Land, Diamond Bay with amusement paks, There are variety of tourist activities for visitors such as seeing corals, playing water sports and tasting fresh ymmy seafood and barbecued pork rolled in rice paper.
3. Vung Tau

Vung Tau is a gem of Southern Vietnam travel. Tourists can see the ocean in both sunrise and sunset while immersing in the sea and get relaxed. It is definitely a paradise for your summer vacation in Vietnam. It has extensive beaches including Back beach and Front Beach that tourists can freely go swimming.
4. Phan Thiet

Located 183 km from Ho Chi Minh City, Phan Thiet has been a famous destination in Vietnam with long sandy beach, aquamarine sea and the poetic coconut paths. Visiting Phan Thiet, you also have chance to see beach of Ke Ga and Tien Thanh, which are peaceful and quiet, inviting tourists to swim and relax in which there is not much traffic on the roads along the coastline. Tourists can enjoy the delicious dishes made from fresh seafoods before walking or riding along the unspoiled beach. It should be considered to be in your shorted lists places of visiting in Vietnam to escape the steaming hot cities for a fresh breeze of sea wind.
5. Phu Quoc

Phu Quoc is the largest island in Vietnam. It is separated from the land with clear and long beaches, the peaceful streams and the unique seafoods. The most famous spots in Phu Quoc are Khem Beach, Sao Beach and Ham Ninh fishing village with two traditional products: fish sauce and black pepper. Specially, one of the best activities you should not miss in Phu Quoc is to dive and contemplate coral. Form March 2014, foreign tourists can visit Phu Quoc with visa-free for a period of up to 30 days.
What are you still waiting for ? First submit your Vietnam visa request at: http://vietnamvisavoa.com/apply-online/ and head to charming Vietnam and enjoy your marvellous summer vacation!

Vietnam is increasingly attractive for many foreigners and many of them consider taking advantage of Indochina’s developing job market and start working in Vietnam. If you are planning on working in Vietnam, it is essential that you understand the aspects to work in Vietnam and the country’s cultural values and traditions.

While working in Vietnam, you will find that Vietnamese companies function in a defined hierarchical manner. The work environment is similar to Asian countries such as China, South Korea and Japan. It is the oldest person in the company who is the decision maker so you should pay respect for your coworkers and partners, especially if they are older than you.The Vietnamese have a healthy work ethic and are generally hardworking and industrious.

Vietnam’s economy has developed well with the government reforms in every key sector of the economy, which are agriculture, food industry, textile, furniture, energy, tourism and telecommunications. All of reforms consist of privatizing public companies, introducing effective moneytary policies and stimulating foreign investments as well.

That is the reason why Vietnam is a very attractive destination for skillful and experienced expats and there are a lot of opportunities for foreigners. However, for most travelers, the main work opportunity is teaching English as a foreign language. English is by far the most popular foreign language with Vietnamese learners. Also, there is some demand for Mandarin and French too. Most foreigners take over many positions in private language centres ($10USD to $18USD per hour) and even home tutoring($15USD to $25USD per hour). Furthermore, some government-run schools from kindergarden to universities in Vietnam also hire some foreign teachers. You can get more chances in Ho Chi Minh city or Hanoi city than in the provinces.
Other jobs are in IT industries, construction and tourism. There are also many NGOs operating out of Vietnam, particularly in Hanoi.

To begin working in Vietnam, expats need to apply for business visa and secure a work permit. Foreigners need to have a work contract and employer who can provide you with further parperworks .The Vietnamese government starts to implement stricter visa regulations which makes it more difficult in the future so any expat wishes to work in Vietnam need to be in possession of a valid work permit.

Expats can either apply for a work permit from within Vietnam or from abroad with the help of their employer or a contracted visa agency. Vietnam visa on arrival offers this service and even make the application form for visa issuance, stay extension for foreigners wishing to work in Vietnam For further information relating to working in Vietnam, how to get work permit and long-term Vietnam visa, please contact us via support@vietnamvisavoa.com to receive the best consulting for any particular situation.

column1: 9567,"[:en]Vietnam Immigration Department: Entry and Exit Formalities[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: Vietnam Immigration Department sets up the regulations about entry and exit for foreigners entering Vietnam with passports and visas as below.
Passports
Your passport must be valid for at least six months upon arrival in Vietnam. Many nationalities need to arrange a visa in advance.
Visas
It is complicated and fast-changing now because some nationalities need a visa in advance for all visits, some don't (for 15 or 30 day stays).

The visa situation has recently changed for many nationalities. The government has eased visa exemption rules, offer visa exemption for more countries and reduced stamping visa fee in a bid to stimulate tourism in Vietnam.
Visa regulation
Firstly, if you are not in the visa exemption list, you need to apply for a Vietnam visa.

There are two ways of applying for a visa: via online visa agent, vietnamvisavoa.com or via a Vietnamese embassy or consulate. Tourist visas are valid for either 30 days or 90 days. For Vietnamvisavoa.com, we offer a good deal for a single-entry 30-day visa with US$18, and US$50 for a three-month multiple entry visa.
Online visa agent: Vietnamviavoa.com

This is the preferred method for most travellers arriving by airplane because it is cheaper, faster and you don't have to take risk posting your passport to Vietnam Embassy. Neverthess, please keep in mind that Vietnam visa on arrival is valid only when you are flying into Vietnam. The process is pretty simple, you just fill out an online application form and pay us the service fee to get an approval letter after 2 working days. You'll then receive a copy of visa on arrival approval letter signed by Vietnam Immigration Department via email. Then, you just need to print out and show on arrival at Vietnam airport. Here, you also have to pay for the stamping fee to get you visa stamped on your passport. With our delicated team, you are able to get a free-hassle trip to Vietnam.
Visas via Vietnam Embassy or Consulate

You can also obtain visas through Vietnamese Embassy/ Consulate throughout the world. However, the fees are normally higher than getting an online visa and the process would be slower depending on the country. In Asia, Vietnamese visas tends to be issued in 4-5 working days.
Visa-exempted nationalities
According to the regulations of Vietnam Immigration Department, citizens of the following countries do not need a Vietnam visa:
Myanmar, Brunei: 14 days
Belarus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, South Korea, Norway, Russia, Spain, Sweden, UK: 15 days
Philippines: 21 days
Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand: 30 days
Visa extension
The procedure can take seven days and you can only extend the visa for 30 or 90 days depending on the visa you are holding. You can ask for help to be organized via agents.
For further information about entry and exit formalities of Vietnam Immigration Department, please contact  us via support@vietnamvisavoa.com or hotline : +84 941 279 289.

column1: 9573,"[:en]What to export from Vietnam: Jobs for expats[:]","[:en]

column2: With the recent trends showing that the Vietnam, which is located in a strategic position for foreign companies with operations throughout Southeast Asia, it is an ideal export hub to reach other ASEAN markets, many foreingers now would like to settle down and work in Vietnam.
They also need to consider what to export from Vietnam so that they could know what are potential aspects that they could consider to work in Vietnam.

Vietnam is widely known for being a prime location or investors operating in the textile industry, there are many other business areas that have proved signifgicant growth in the country. It is becoming a key location for high-technology manufacturing with companies like Samsung, LG, Electronics etc. Other businesses aspects consist of information and commuinications technology, automotive and medical devices.
The American Chamber of Commerce estimates that bilateral trade with the U.S will surge to $57 USD billion by 2020, cementing Vietnam’s prominence as a valuable hub for foreign investment.
Textiles and Garments

Textiles is  among Vietnam’s leading export industry with employment upwards of 1.3 million workers in directly related jobs and more than two million with auxiliary work included. The growth of the garment industry has been considerably significant.

Within ASEAN, Vietnam is the strongest competitor for inheriting low value-added textiles and apparel manufacturing from China. In contrast to other leading textile exporters in the region (Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia), the share of Vietnam’s textile exports against its total exports has grown in recent years.
In terms of revenue, footwear is Vietnam’s third most productive export industry, generating US$ 8.5 billion in 2013. The country produces 800 million pairs of shoes per year.
Electronics

Vietnam has been considered as an important electronics exporter with electrical and electronic products overtaking coffee, textiles, and rice to become the country’s top export item. Samsung is Vietnam’s largest exporter, which helps the country achieve a trade surplus for the first time in many years. Exports of smartphones and computer parts now account for more in export earnings than oil and garments. Samsung is attempting to turn Vietnam into a global manufacturing base for its products and has invested for over US$ 10 billion into the country.

Samsung has agreed to cooperate with Vietnamese government in order to develop the country’s domestic support industries. This represents a key business opportunity for foreign technology companies to set up operations in Vietnam and sell their components to companies like Samsung.
Pharmaceuticals

The future looks tobe very interesting for the pharmaceutical industry in Vietnam. Recent economic forecasts have predicted a US$ 5 billion increase in value over the next six years, reaching a net worth of US$ 8 billion by 2020 – a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 15.4 percent. Driving this market growth is the Vietnamese government’s goal of achieving universal health coverage by 2015. 30% of the country’s population still has no form of public health insurance.
Automotive

Vietnam is becoming an important market for auto sales – August was the 17th consecutive month of sales growth, with a 59 percent year on year increase and total sales of 12,562 units. Interestingly, despite the country’s recent economic struggles, the luxury car market has continued to see healthy growth.

Despite an increasingly competitive auto market throughout the ASEAN region, Vietnam has stated that it intends to work aggressively to build up its own domestic auto industry. The key reason for this goal is that the auto industry has the potential to create thousands of jobs for locals and create a strong system of supporting industries.
Coffee

Vietnam becomes  the world’s largest producer and exporter of coffee. Currently, the country is the world’s second largest coffee exporter, behind only Brazil. However, many experts believe that Vietnam has the potential to overtake Brazil thanks to such factors as favorable climate conditions and lower cost production. In recent years, coffee has become one of Vietnam’s key agricultural export products – with 95 percent of output being shipped abroad.
E-commerce

Vietnam is quickly becoming a prime market for foreign investment in e-commerce activities. The country’s rapidly growing economy and middle class are, in turn, spawning a strong consumer culture and increasing levels of disposable income. Electronic retail is fast becoming the preferred method of shopping—particularly among the country’s youth. It is predicted that in 2015 Vietnam will see more than US$ 4 billion in B2C e-commerce sales – current sales are estimated at around US$ 2.2 billion, with an average spending of US$ 120 per capita.

By 2016, internet penetration in Vietnam will reach 43 million people – 40-45 percent of the total population. This percentage is thought to be the “golden proportion” at which investors will pour into the e-commerce market.
Source: Vietnam Briefing February 3, 2015
For further information about what to export form Vietnam, jobs oppotunity for expats in Vietnam, please contact us via support@vietnamvisavoa.com

If you are Laos citizens, you  are offered Vietnam visa exemption for 30 days, unless you wish to stay longer than this period, you do not need a Vietnam visa for entering Vietnam.

If you are not exempted from Vietnam visa, a valid Vietnam visa is required for you.  It is  easy to get a Vietnamese visa in Vientiane, Laos through Vietnamese Embassy. It may take 3 working days to process.

column1: 9616,"[:en] How to travel by land from China to Vietnam ? [:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: To travel by land from China to Vietnam, it seems to be quite easy because there are quite a lot of Vietnam - China border crossings. These borders are very crowded everytime and known as ideal places for doing business.
There are three border crossings between China and Vietnam, namely Mong Cai (Vietnam)/ Dong Hung (China), Dong Dang/ Ping Xian, and Lao Cai/ Hekou.

All border crossings are in the Northeast of Vietnam. It is easy to get to Mong Cai from Quang Ninh province or Halong City while from Sapa, Lao Cai, tourists could find the fastest way to Kunning through Lao Cai/Hekou border gate. If departing from Lang Son and heading to China, you had better to get to Dong Dang/ Ping Xian border gate and conversely, coming from China through Dong Dang border gate, you certainly get to Hanoi easily thanks to a variety of buses or trains.

Even there is definitely a train from Nanning to Hanoi and it departs every Monday and Friday, you just need to buy ticket in Nanning in advance for  a better trip in case it is very crowded. This is also by far the cheapest way to travel from China to Vietnam.

If you are a Chinese citizen, you must be in possession of a Vietnam visa. As you travel by land, it is required to get a Vietnam visa in your hand before you leave China.You can apply for Vietnam visa at the Consulate of Vietnam :
Address: GuangXi Investment Building, Floor 3, 109 Minzu Dadao, NanNing, GuangXi Zhuang Auto Region 530000
Tel: +86-(0)-138-7710-0849

How to travel around Vietnam ? To come to Vietnam, first, you must consider about your passport, visa then select some means of transports which are suitable for you during your trip around Vietnam. For foreign tourists, you wil need a passport with at least six-month validity to enter Vietnam. Most tourists who are not from exempted-visa coutries normally enter Vietnam on a tourist visa. This visa could be arranged at Vietnam Embassy or you can apply for visa online at vietnamvisavoa.com to get stamped visa on arrival. Your visa validity will start on the arrival date that you submit in the visa form then as soon as you make plan for your trip, you could start your order.
Below are the popular transportations which are used by travellers to get around Vietnam during their trip.
By road
Traveling by road should be approached with caution as it can be rather dangerous, especially for long distant buses. It might be nice to use mix of travel modes of plane, train, bus etc.
By plane

Vietnam Airlines is Vietnam’s national carrier with comprehensive domestic network and international ones and operates daily flights between Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh city, Hue, Da Nang and Nha Trang. Jetstar is the second one with a more limited network. Jetstar Pacific also operates flights on these routes. Flights are particularly busy around the Tet holidays so it is better to book ticket ahead.

Traveling around Vietnam is pretty easy to do it yourself if you spend more time on setting up plan and if you want to have budget trip. Vietnam is not really good enough for tourists to see much at all for  several days only as Vietnam is larger than it appears to be on those tiny maps. You can see most of majour places that travelers visit frequently starting from the North, the Central and the South.
By train

Vietnam's train system is a lot better than it used to be. It is not all that cheap but it is comfortable, exceddingly scenic in places and an overall very interesting and fun way to travel. If you are travelling in high season or especially over Tet holiday, you had better book in advance as soon as possible.
By motorbike

It is very popular for backpackers to rent motorbike. Especially, motorbile is very popular in Vietnam that most Vietnam adults since 18 years old upward can own their own motorbike. Bikes for traveling can be purchased for as litte as a few hundred US dollars. After that, you can sell the bile off to another travelers with not too many troubles.
By bike

Vietnam can be a great destination for cyclists. There are some adventure travel tour companies who can support you in this or you can just join locals on two wheels and go out there for yourself. It is cheap enough to rent bikes in the big cities and Dalat, Hoi An, Hue and Ninh Binh are popular as great places for cycling.
By boat

This is great option for Ha Long Bay to stay on a boat with 1 to 3 day boat trip around the limestone islands and caves.  It is also popular in the Mekong Delta, where youcan travel in both tourist boats and take freighters for longer trips.
By taxi

Taxis with meters found in most major cities and are very cheap and safe to travel around at night. Average tariffs are about 12,000 to 15,000 d per kilometer. Two nationawide companies with excellent reputations are Mai Linh and Taxi Group.
By Xe Om

Its another name is a motorbike taxi. Getting around by Xe Om is easy if you do not bring lots of luggage.Fares should be negotiated beforehand as there are many xe om drivers hanging around street corners, markets, hotels and bus stations.
For further information about how to travel around Vietnam, please contact us via support@vietnamvisavoa.com or via hotline: +84.941279289.

column1: 9632,"[:en]Local transport fares for traveling in Vietnam[:]","[:en]

column2: Local transport fares

For most visitors, one of the most important aspect of traveling in Vietnam is fare of transport. Most people feel quite annoying when they are being ripped off. Here are some basic information to help you travel safely and comfortably during your trips in Vietnam.
Airfares
It is dependent on when you book and what dates you want to travel. You do not need to worry about the prices of traveling by plane as ther is no price difference between Vietnamese and foreigners.
Bus fares
It is more complicated and you should buy a ticket from the point of departure as the price is fixed and very reasonable. The bus systems in Hanoi and HCMC are not impossible to negotiate.

It is not really good shoud you board a bus along the way as the driver can overcharge. In remote area, drivers may ask for double what the locals pay. Sometimes, local bus fee can be fixed and displayed by the door or boarding news.
Rail fares
It is fixed and prices for different classes is different.
Taxis
Mostly metered  and very cheap but some taxies have dodgy meters that run fast and you should take reliable taxi brand name in Vietnam (Taxi Group, Mai Linh in Hanoi or  Vina Sun in Ho Chi Minh).
Xe Om and cylcos

Fares are not fixed and you need to bargain. Fares are comparable with those for a cyclo, but negotiate the price beforehand. There are plenty of xe om drivers hanging around street corners, markets, hotels and bus stations.
The cyclo is a bicycle rickshaw. This cheap, environmentally friendly mode of transport is steadily dying out, but is still found in Vietnam’s main cities.

Groups of cyclo drivers always hang out near major hotels and markets, and many speak at least broken English. To make sure the driver understands where you want to go, it’s useful to bring a city map. Bargaining is imperative. Settle on a fare before going anywhere or you’re likely to get stiffed.
Approximate fares are between 20,000d and 30,0000d for a short ride, between 40,000d and 50,000d for a longer or night ride, or around 60,000d per hour.
Boat fares
Ferries have fixed prices, however, you might pay more for the privilege of being a foreigner on smaller local boats around the Mekong Delta.
For further information about local transport fares for traveling in Vietnam, please contact us via support@vietnamvisavoa.com or via hotline: (084) 94 127 92 89.

column1: 9679,"[:en]8 reasons to choose Vietnam for holiday[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: Many people, include foreign students choose Vietnam as their perfect place to spend their break. Here are 8 reasons to choose Vietnam for visiting that you should check it out.
1. It’s cheap

One of the reasons to choose Vietnam for visiting is that it is cheap. You won’t have to worry about spending too much money here because Vietnam was ranked on the list of countries for travelling with the lowest price in the world. You can get by with about $20/day and it includes a guest house, local food (noodles, bread, sticky rice etc), transport (bus, motorbike etc) and drink(sugar cane juice, iced tea, iced coffee etc). Furthermore, it is easy to find a hostel or hotel with a fair quality and the reasonable price or you can find homestay where you can have good opportunities to learn more about Vietnamese culture.
2. It’s cheerful

For those who are not fluent in Vietnamese, you still get your smile as Vietnamese people will welcome you with friendly smiles and warm greetings from children to adults alike. Everyone is kind and enthusiastic. If you ask for any information or need some help, they will be honest to help you with their pleasure. Even some Vietnamese people don't know foreign language, however, they still show their friendliness to all travellers. Is it good enough to be in your list among reasons to choose Vietnam? What is greater than being welcomed by locals every where you go in Vietnam?
3. It’s relaxing

You can get away from the busy life and stay in the gorgeous beaches or islands such as Phu Quoc, Con Dao; look at the sunrise at Nha Trang, Mui Ne, Quy Nhon. What is better to clear your head after exams than sinking your toes into some white sand and walk along the stretch of sand and listen to waves. If you are thrill seekers, water sport activities might be of your interest. You can explore by scuba diving, surfing, snorkeling, kite surfing etc.
4. Eat like a king

You can try tasty meals other than restaurants in Vietnam. You just take a look at the street sidewalks or alley, you can find surprisingly delicious food. You can enjoy a meal out which is the most interesting way to explore the daily life of locals. Seafood here is fresh and cheap. Hanoi is home to the country’s best street food vendors.
5. History comes alive

You can actually hear history about the past from living Vietnamese locals instead of reading it in a textbook. Many museums that run guided intros to Vietnam’s ancient history, right up to the disasters of the 20th century. You can visit the War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh, the Museum of Vietnamese History, the Ho Chi Minh museum etc.
6. Places of beauty

Although Vietnam is a small country but the nature brings so much things for Vietnam so that they are gems with World Heritage Sites like Phong Nha-Ke Bang National Park, Ha Long Bay, My Son Sanctuary, Hoi An ancient town, Dong Van Karst Plateau Geopark etc. You also must overwhelmed by the world’s largest cave Son Doong. There are so many things to discover and keep unforgettable moments when you set food onto Vietnam that deserves to be one of the reasons to choose Vietnam for visiting.
7. The morning commute

You can take a bike because it is easy for you to get around Vietnam, particularly in rural areas. You will clear your head, block out some of the noise from the big cities and enjoy morning with some of the world’s most beautiful scenery.
8. Redecorate your walls

Hanoi is bursting with galleries and with a bit of haggling, you can pick up some original art or find some beautiful pieces at the night markets. You can see many famous artworks that are cleverly reproduced in Hanoi’s Old Quarter. Simply strolling along Nguyen Thai Hoc street you can find some galleries as your fancy.

column1: 9700,"[:en]When is the best time to visit Vietnam?[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: When is the best time to visit Vietnam? It is difficult to say as ideal destinations in each region will be various.
Vietnam has different weather patterns from North to South and will give each time in the year an advantage. Here are months that you can consider to visit with throughout Vietnam.
From January to March

Vietnam weather between January and March has cool and cold weather in the North while it is warm and dry in the Centre and the South. Temperature in Sapa can drop to near 0 Celcius degree and in Ho Chi Minh city, it ranges from 28 to 35 Celcius degree. This time has abundant festivals taking place all over the country.
From April to June

The season transforms from spring to summer. In the South, we can experience cool weather with occasional light rain. In June, temperature and humidity rises. The center of Vietnam remains wet with temperature weather until May while the South and Southern coast are in hot dry weather.

What place is the best to visit during these time ? You might visit Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh city during April 30th- May 2nd, which are the holiday in Vietnam and you will find fewer traffic congestion, nicer fresh air and perfect time to visit museums and tourist destinations.
From June to early September

During this time, many family holidays in almost resorts or beaches of Vietnam. It sees a record high in domestic tourists volume. Many popular places like Ha Long Bay, Da Nang beach, Nha Trang beach, Phu Quoc island are always crowded with lines of travelers.

The weather is wet and hot. It does not sound like an ideal time for traveling but for beaches and sun lovers. You can see sunrise shining from 6 A.M to 6 P.M. You should avoid travelling in these places during weekends.
From Mid-September to December

It is a good time to visit the North of Vietnam: Hanoi, Sapa, Ha Long bay  with clear sky and gentle wind. When its gets to December, temperature drops lower. In Hanoi, it lures tourists with romantic places in the evening in parallel with colonial buildings here. It is the best time to visit Vietnam, to Sapa as it will charm you with beautiful color of terraced rice paddy fields for harvesting. Dry air will make the trip more enjoyable with Hanoi’s romance and tranquility.

However, in the South, in October and November, it is rainy months and the damp weather could spoil your holiday with the sun and beach. In Central of Vietnam, it often rains dogs and cats in November and December, especially in Hue and Hoi An.
Further information about best time to visit Vietnam should be discussed via support@vietnamvisavoa.com.

Ancient and peaceful, Hoi An is one of the most popular destinations in Vietnam that offer travellers from all walks of life all tastes. The little ancient town is just a perfect candidate of what Vietnam tourism ministry is aiming to show to the world.One of the best thing you must notice when you visit Hoi An is a variety range of special local foods. If you are going to Hoi An, and still consider What to eat in Hoi An, you should note down 5 best local foods of this lantern land in Vietnam.
1. Cao Lau

This is the first specialty you should think of in the list of  "What to eat in Hoi An". Cao Lau is considered Hoi An’s signature dish that you could not miss if you come to Hoi An. Cao Lau is a special type of golden brown noodle. It serves with bean sprouts, barbecue pork, fried pork skin and greaves with a little bit special sauce, fragrant dough and raw vegetables.

It is one of the best local foods in Hoian as water as it must come from an ancient Cham wells around Hoi An. Also, vegetable has to be taken from Tra Que vegetable village. Furthermore, the ashes which use to soak the noodle have to be taken from Cham Island. What can be more delicious than this ?
2. Hoi An chicken rice

It is one of the delights that you should try as many travel magazine and flyers vote for it. Hoi An chicken rice is very eye-catching dish with bright yellow color of rice, green salad and white chicken meat, or can be added with a red chilly, too. The mixture of rice with boiled, coarsely shredded chicken and crushed onions, Vietnamese coriander make customers irresistible.
3. Quang Noodles

The noodle is made from rice flour with yellow or white color. It is mixed with shrimp, pork, baked bread, vegetables and topped with grilled rice paper and spices. It is served with very little broth and seems like a dry noodle dish or noodle salad. It is very delicious with the crushed peanut toppings on the noodles.
4. Hoanh Thanh (Wonton)

There are three forms: soup, fried wonton and noodle. Its ingredients include flour, eggs and shrimp. After blending, flour and eggs are cut into small square pieces. The inside includes crushed spiced shrimp. Its broth is cooked with pineapple, tomatoes and mushrooms. It is a perfect combination of the dishes with small green vegetables.
5. Bread

Hoi An is one of vietnam’s addresses that is famous for bread. It is praised by international press for its tasty burger. It serves with pate, steak, herbs and special sauces. It is very attractive with crispy crust and its fleshy inside. You don't need to worry about What to eat in Hoi An any more.

Many foreigners consider to stay, work in another countries worry about adjusting to new climatic conditions. It is a key in any expatriation process and even moving to Vietnam to adapt to climate characteristics of Vietnam is no exception.

Climate characteristics of Vietnam vary on different geographical feature. If you live on the plains in Vietnam, there will be several months every year that are very hot and so humid. You can feel it like you are breathing under water. You sweat a lot but you don't cool down. Your clothes just get wet all the time being out. If you live in the mountains, it is expected to be cool to cold weather for several months every year. Sapa on the Chinese border even gets snow every few years in the winter only.

Hanoi has four seasons, with winter around Christmas-New Year time and summer in the middle of the year. Saigon and the Mekong delta have three seasons: the hot and dry from the middle of November to the middle of January, very hot and dry from the middle of January to the middle of May and the very hot and wet season from the middle of May to the middle of November. Nha Trang wet season is from September until January, with floods most common in November, and summer is from June to August. Sometimes, it can be hot anytime from March onwards in some years.
How does the local weather impact your daily life ?

Lots of locals and expats get sweat rash and skin problems in summer. Expats can get various illnesses caused by not drinking enough water. On the plains, the locals start to get colds and flu as soon as the temperature drops below 27 Celsius.

In wet season, don't even think about going out in the rain, unless you take complete change of clothes with you. No matter what raincoat or umbrella you use, you will still get wet. Expats do what the locals do by just pulling over under any awning and waiting for half an hour until it stops to rain. Regular flooding in many parts of Vietnam prevents travel and commuting to work in wet season.
As in other parts of the world, you get used to the climate where ever you live. You have to  accept the heat, accept the cold, accept the floods and adapt to them.
Further information about climate characteristics of Vietnam, please contact vietnamvisavoa.com via support@vietnamvisavoa.com or hotline: +8494 127 92 89.
Vietnam visa exemption news: 2016
Updates on 1st July, 2016:

According to the Decree No. 56/NQ-CP, passport holders from countries: the UK, France, Italy, Germany and Spain will still get 15 days Vietnam visa exemption for another 1 year ( from July 1st, 2016 to June 30th, 2017)

The Vietnamese Government has decided to apply the waiver for visitors by an additional year for tourists from the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain with the aims to lure the number of more foreign visitors to Vietnam and to boost the domestic tourism.
The visa exemption for the five Western European countries has contributed considerably to Vietnamese tourism development over the past year.
Conditions to get 15-day visa exemption are as follows:
-Their passport is valid for at least 6 months from their arrival date;
-Their stay in Vietnam is no more than 15 days;

-Their arrival date is not within 30 days from date of exit of their last visit to Vietnam with visa exemption. Otherwise, a valid Vietnam visa is required. You just need to apply forVietnam visa online at vietnamvisavoa.com to get a Vietnam visa on arrival.

In case you are staying in Vietnam more than 15 days, a Vietnam visa is highly recommended for you. You just need to submit a visa request online at: vietnamvisavoa.com to get a Vietnamese visa approval letter via email. Upon arrival airport, you will receive your stamped visa. While you are staying in Vietnam, you will not need to worry about Vietnam visa extension which wastes your money and money.

column1: 9783,"[:en]Health insurance for expats in Vietnam[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: Health insurance for expats in Vietnam is better in private hospitals.

Most citizens of Vietnam have to pay for medical services themselves at both private and public hospitals. In many cases, Vietnamese people prefer private hospitals to the public ones because of the services and equipments. The standard of public hospitals are generally underfunded and poorly equipped. They also are not similar to that of hospitals in Western countries.

One thing expats should acknowledge that doctors and medical staff working at public hospitals in Vietnam will normally only speak Vietnamese. Health insurance for expats in Vietnam might know that the standard of private hospitals in Vietnam is better and it will be nicer in big cities, in Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh city because there are staffs, doctors from the US, Korea, Japan etc. They tend to cater for the demands of expats better than public hospitals.

The expense varies considerably. You can imagine that while prices are still lower than the rates charged in Western countries, specialists who market themselves for the expat market in Vietnam will charge more than those that work with locals. It is obvious that doctors and medical staff at private hospitals in Vietnam speak English and/or French, which makes life easier for expats.

To hospitals in Vietnam, expats should check with both the hospital and their insurance provider that they are covered. Pharmacies in Vietnam easy to find in the crowded areas such as urbans, apartment buildings, in major shopping street or mall, especially in big cities such as Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City.

In Vietnam, buying medicine over the counter without a prescription is straightforward, however,  they should be aware that medicines are always checked the date on the packaging before making a purchase. In addition, expats who want to be extra careful can take necessary medicines from their home country, or visit a pharmacy in one of the private hospitals.

Expats should avoid drinking tap water in Vietnam and buy bottled water instead.  In most restaurants, ice is made from boiled water so expats with sensitive stomaches might want to be safe in precaution.

Infectious diseases and health threats that expats moving to Vietnam should be aware of are Hepatitis A and B, especially in the countryside where hygiene standards are not always maintained. They should equip themselves with typhoid, dengue fever and malaria, especially in rural parts of Vietnam and make sure that they are on a course of anti-malarial tablets.

The emergency services number in Vietnam is 115. However, it is bad that ambulances in Vietnam are known for having a slow response time and paramedics do not always speak English and equipment may be substandard, too.

There are no special immunisations required for those travelling or moving to Vietnam. So, expats moving to Vietnam should ensure that their vaccinations of Hepatitis A, Hepatitis B, Tetanus, Diphtheria, Rabies (optional, but advisable for those travelling or working in rural areas)
Please notice that a yellow fever vaccination certificate is required for travelers arriving from yellow fever zones in South America or Africa.

column1: 9827,"[:en]How to get to Hanoi from airport? [:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: - How to get to Hanoi from airport ?
- There are choices for you to choose to get to Ha Noi city from Hanoi/ Noi Bai Airport: airline transfer service, taxi, airport pick-up service from hotels or from travel agency, public bus.

Hanoi’s Noi Bai International Airport is located 45 kilometres far from the central Hanoi. If you arrive in Hanoi airport late in the evening, you should take or book a taxi or hotel pick-up in advance because the buses stop running before the last flights and most taxis will charge high price, refusing to stick to the stated price.
Private minibuses

The private minibuses expect to leave as soon as it is full, which usually doesn't take long. This option is popular with locals because the bus will stop off a few times to drop people off along the way without any exact place . However, it should be central or good enough to walk or take a short taxi ride to where you do want to arrive. However, you just prepare to be flexible and notice that the drivers don’t speak English.
Airline transfer service
Jetstar, Vietnam Airlines  run transfer service when you book your ticket, you can check for the price, around $ 2 USD/ pax to city center.
Taxi

There are so many taxi drivers at the airport, waiting to catch customers and  might over-charge, so if you are approached by an individual driver, you should politely say NO and make your way outside to the official taxi ranks.
Airport pick-up

Most hotels will arrange this for you if you’ve pre-booked a room. They may charge a bit more than the taxis at the airport but the benefit is that they arrange someone waiting for you at the airport and you’re almost guaranteed to get taken to the right hotel.

If you take our car service at the airport, we also take our driver to get you back your hotel in the central with decent price and guaranteed service. When you apply for Vietnam visa online with vietnamvisavoa.com, remember to book our car service and make payment online. We will arrange every service once your payment is confirmed.
Public bus

Hanoi city buses number 7 and 17 connect Noi Bai Airport with Hanoi city center. The bus stop is just on the right side of the terminal exit and costs 9,000 VND per person and takes about one hour. Buses run every 15-20 minutes from 5 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Further information about How to get to Hanoi from airport ? will be provided via support@vietnamvisavoa.com or hotline: (+84) 94 127 92 89.

- What is the best time to visit Hanoi ?
- The best time to travel in Hanoi is from November to February.

The most beautiful season and the best time to visit Vietnam is between September and March, many tourists choose to travel to tourist destinations like: Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh city, Ha Long, Sapa, Phu Quoc island etc.

Autumn which is the most beautiful time in the year. The air gets cleaner and the landscape is fantastic. From September to November, especially October is the best time to pay a visit to Hanoi city. In Hanoi, it is so hot in summer and you should avoid Hanoi at this time if you do not like the heat of Hanoi. In contrary, for local people, it is time for beach holiday of families and friends, as a result, all of tourist destinations are overcrowded and services are overcharged.

In summer, you often catch heavy rains and some big storms in Hanoi. Many streets will be flooded and travelling can face with many difficulties. Because of this, your flights, your tour programme could be delayed or cancelled at a very short notice.
In winter, it is time for many traditional festivals: Vietnamese Lunar New Year but the weather of this season is not good enough. Extremely cold!
In summary, the answer for the question: What is the best time to visit Hanoi?  It is the autumn.

column1: 9841,"[:en]How to set up a business in Vietnam?[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: In recent years, Vietnam is not only well known for tourists but also for business people. The first and foremost issue that businessmen would consider is how to set up a business in Vietnam.
Setting up a business in Vietnam requires you to know about the existing laws in terms of investment as well as the types of businesses you can do.

You must obtain an authorization of entry which will allow you to apply for a business visa to Vietnam. You then need a partner in the country, who can be Vietnamese or from foreign origin. You will have to communicate him/her personally for the application. Once you have obtained your authorization of entry, you can go to Vietnam Embassy or Consulate in your country to apply for Vietnam visa.

You also can apply for DN visa online. If you work in a company in Vietnam, let ask your company to get your visa sponsored. You also can apply for business visa with vietnamvisavoa.com. You just need to send us your passport copy to email: support@vietnamvisavoa.com. We then check the information and inform you to pay for service fee. We will get your visa approval letter done within 5 working days. You will fly into Vietnam with this document and then get stamped visa at Vietnam Airport.

There is no legal minimum or maximum capital regardless of the type of business you choose to create in Vietnam. You can invest either in local currency, Vietnamese Dong or in convertible foreign currency. You must also determine the status of your company, stating the name and address of the head office and branches of your business, the area in which you intend to invest.

You must specify if it is a collective society mentioning the names and nationality of your business partners having an organizational and management plan for your company. You will have to hire a legal representative to assist you with the procedures.

You then register your company with the Provincial People's Committee closest to your company's head office. In fact, you are required to send a completed application by producing the following documents:
· Status report of the company
· The list of shareholders or members and a copy of their identity card or passport
· If the shareholder is a foreign company: a copy of the registration certificate
· The certificate of paid-up capital for the establishment of the company
· The exercise certificates of directors or associates.

The registration certificate should be issued within ten days from the date of submission of the request. You also need to make sure that your business activities are legal in Vietnam and that the name given to the company complies with the provisions of Vietnamese law.
Once you have obtained the registration certificate, you have to publish information about your company on the registration office website.
Your company will be subject to income tax once you have registered with the Revenue Department of the Vietnamese Ministry of Finance.

Ministry of Finance of Vietnam www.mof.gov.vn
Doing Business www.doingbusiness.org

"-What to see in Sapa?
-There are lots of things for you to do in Sapa with many activities such as visiting cultural travelling to villages, going shopping at ethnic minority markets."

Sapa is a touristy town of the far North of Vietnam. It is a great place for trekking lovers among terraced rice paddies, mountains and green stretches. The best time to visit Sapa is in Summer months from August to December.
Bac Ha village

It takes three hour away from Sapa town.Visitors can enjoy the Sunday markets and former Hmong King's palace here. It features local scenes that happen on every week for generations. There are cattles, horses, goats and dogs bought and sold and many traditional goods like saddles plus elaborate textiles, handbags and other trinkets made by the local tribes people, the Flower Hmong, too. Their intricately woven daily costume is one of the main drawing points in itself, which is an incredibly beautiful part of Vietnam.
Cat Cat and Sin Chai villages

They are respectively 3km and 7km away from downtown Sapa. Those love treking always love the scenery paths to these villages. Magnificent mountains and terraced paddy fields are still attractive to every tourists.
Sapa Markets
It is situated in a large pit at the heart of Sapa town. It is a nice place to buy local crafts from embroidery to horn carvings.
Ta Phin and the French monastery ruins
The village of ethnic Red Dao is 10km away from Sapa. You can either hire a taxi or a taxi motorbike to get there.
Thac Bac (Silver Fall)
It is about 11km away from Sapa, Thac Bac (Silver Fall) is modest in size but far from being humble in beauty.
Tram Ton Pass

From Thac Bac, you can walk to Tram Ton Pass, which is the highest mountain pass in Vietnam. If you can enjoy the view in a sunny day, it is spectacular. Even in misty days, you would love the feeling of floating among white 'clouds'.

column1: 9883,"[:en]How much does English teachers earn in Vietnam ?[:]","[:en]

column2: Are you seeking for a chance  to travel and work in Vietnam? Why not becoming an English teacher in Vietnam with so many fascinating benefits ?

Teaching English in Vietnam become popular for most expats. When English is an international language and the demand for learning English in Vietnam is on the rise , the number of English speakers in Vietnam increases incredibly.
More importantly, English teachers in Vietnam earn a very attractive income is the condition for many expats choose to stay in Vietnam and work as a English teacher.
English teaching salary in Vietnam

In general, an English teacher in Vietnam can earn from US$800 to over US$2,000 a month depend upon the number of teaching hours and his/her qualification as well as their appearance. Let say that, a native English speaker, if they teach regularly, they are able to earn US$2,500/ month. This income will be the luxury dream of millions of Vietnamese. Accordingly,  this teaching job brings a comfortable life to expats in Vietnam. The cost of renting an accommodation makes up the majority. In addition, other costs such as food, transportation and other services are also lower than most of countries in the region. Hence, with that salary, English teachers can cover all living expense and save their earnings for travel easily.

As global integration is essential for Vietnam as other countries, demands for learning English and opportunities for English teacher are increasing. It is easily recognized a huge job opportunity for every foreigner considering Vietnam for working or just traveling. For high-qualified and confidential English teachers, they always find a job with best conditions and attractive salary.

Even many travelers prefer living in Vietnam for a short period, teaching English in Vietnam, yet, their favorite, especially teaching English in kindergartens and English language centers. Even for many expats, they can earn money in Vietnam as English teacher for a few months and then save money to continue travelling or coming back home easily.

For those who are inexperience, they choose to be private tutor, give private lesson to one or some students in their hourse. Others could find teaching jobs pretty simple in English language centers or schools.

For preparation of curriculum, teachers do not have much things to do, the school need to create teaching schedule based on the curriculum and reference materials, teacher just need to perform it. Other activities in the class will be added to attract students's attention.

Teaching hours in Vietnam is about 40 hours per week for a full-time teacher, including 20 hours for teaching, and for preparing curriculum. A part-time teacher spends about 11-12 hours per week, and he or she will be assigned at least three classes per week.
What certificate is required ?

It was said that foreign teachers were obliged to get a TESOL or CELTA in other countries before arriving in Vietnam. However, these days, they can get those certificates in Vietnam relatively simple. TESOL and CELTA which are issued in Vietnam also have the same validity as certificates issued in other countries.

Furthermore, the charge for CELTA and TESOL in Vietnam are much lower than in the U.S. Enrolling the course for one month with just $ US 1.500, you will get all theoretical and practical tests as well as certificate.
Let apply online to get Vietnam visa online easily and start your fun teaching career in Vietnam.

Jobs for expats in Vietnam is attracting for a large number of expats to find a better job and suitable for their qualifications. In addition, many expat jobs in Vietnam appeal great interest of foreigners.

As being a developing economy, there is a variety of jobs for foreigners in Vietnam, especially in big cities like Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh city. Fields attract expats including IT industries, construction and tourism, and a  large number of foreigners come to Vietnam and simply work as English teachers in schools language communities, and NGOs.

It can be seen that Vietnam is lacking high-qualified labor, thus, foreigners come to Vietnam to seek for a job seems to be the factor filling in the gap in some specific fields. Expat jobs in Vietnam can be easily found in quite a few websites. There is a wide range of reputable job seeking websites which provides expats chances to find suitable jobs such as: Vietnam Works, Job Street, Career Link, Lao Dong, Tuoitre, Career Jet, Learn4Good whist Vietnam Works is regarded as the most reputable job-seeking website in Vietnam, which contains a large number of famous corporations and companies, even non-profitable organizations. Thus, foreigners will have numerous job opportunities in this young economy.

The reason why most of foreigners come to Vietnam and choose to teach English as most language centers and school system in Vietnam prefer hiring foreign teachers to improve the quality of education in Vietnam, especially in linguistics development. Many teaching and training opportunities for foreigners are created. Foreigners teaching in Vietnam are often paid for about US$15 – US$25 per hour in some fields such as linguistics and training technique. English teaching is not only popular in big cities as Hanoi or Ho Chi Minh City, but also other provinces. Moreoever, being employed as English teacher does not require high education and long experience. As long as you could speak a moderate English and have some English teaching certificates like: Tesol, Tefl, Celta... you will be able to find English teaching job with just some clicks.

Besides working in the education sectors, expats can find jobs in other fields such as being high-ranking officers in some large corporations, private businesses, or foreign-owned companies. Many foreigners work in fields of business development and sales. Many Vietnamese companies hire foreign personnel due to their good qualification of English as well as working ethics. Currently, most partners of companies in Vietnam are foreigners, so when negotiate to cooperate, officers as expats might succeed more than that of Vietnamese people. Vacancies in tourism and constructions are also interesting jobs in Vietnam for expats as these fields require skilled-labor specialists.

column1: 9890,"[:en]Work for expats in Nha Trang[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: Working in Nha Trang city seems to be very interesting for many expats in Vietnam as it is the worth-living city of Vietnam.

Nha Trang city, which is located in the province of Khanh Hoa, Vietnam is mainly a tourist area. With a big number of foreigners wishing to work and stay in this wonderful coastal city with this favourable weather, the Vietnamese government has endeavored to accelerate the economic growth and give it a new dynamism.  Many job oppotunities for expats here, especially for tourism aspect. If you are looking for a job there, you need to know which field suits you best and make sure that you have adequate qualifications for performing jobs which is not available for local Vietnamese people.

With the attractions of more than one million tourists each year in Nha Trang, tourism is one of the main pillars of its economy, accounting to some 43% of its Gross Domestic Product (GDP). Moreover, because of very ideal weather, environment and numerous natural resources, Vietnamese government aims to accelerate the city's economic growth and sustainable development to be known as the economic, cultural and tourist center of Vietnam. The objective is to foster a 12-13 % growth rate per year in this province.

Furthermore, other sectors such as farming, mining, processing and export of aquatic products, transportation, services and construction also contribute to the city's GDP. It can be easily seen that rattan production plant which is mainly dedicated to export, mineral water manufactures which contribute to the city's economy.

For a few years, quite a lot of national and international companies have set up in this region, creates a labor pool not only for local but for expatriates also. You can definitely apply for a job in the fields of hospitality, exports, services, trade and real estate if you meet job requirements.
On the other hand, the maritime sector, particularly aquaculture, is generating some ten thousands of jobs each year. The city has a preserved maritime area involving many trading partners.

Are you going to visit Hanoi city and you are wondering what are the attractions that you can visit for free in Hanoi? You might be surprised because of the list that the capital of Vietnam with all the busiest businesses and entertainment can offer for free.
1. Tran Quoc Pagoda
Tran Quoc Pagoda is the oldest pagoda in Hanoi that offers beautiful architecture, historic artifacts and a peaceful, serene environment. You can visit for free everday from 8:00A.M to 18:00P.M.

The pagoda was built in the sixth century during the reign of Ly Nam De. It is famous for a tall tower visible from the street and with 15 metres high and has 11 tiers shaped the petals of a lotus flower and the statues worshipping Buddha system and the priceless antiques there. You can consider what you can visit for free in Hanoi but it is still very interesting and Tran Quoc pagoda is worth to be in your list.

The courtyard at the back is home to a large shrine and an even larger Bodhi tree, which was presented to the pagoda by the Prime Minister of India in 1959 and creates welcome shade under its immense breadth.
2. Saint Josheph Cathedral

It follows the Roman Catholic Cathedral with neo-gothic style and was built about 120 years back. The cathedral with its beautiful architecture and good venue at the center of the city, is always packed with hundreds of local people and tourists hanging out with friends for drinking, talking, and watching the street surrounding the cathedral.

It is not only the place that you can see for free but you can experience with the entertainment of people in the “Lemon Tea” street around the church. It is the answer for "What I can visit for free in Hanoi?". It is a popular gathering for many young people in Hanoi, and home to eye-catching souvenir shops and Western style restaurants. It is not only the holly place for Christian couples hold their wedding, but also a great venue for non- religious grooms and brides to take nice wedding pictures.
3. Dong Xuan Market

Dong Xuan Market, which is established in 1989 is housed of a four-storey Soviet-style building on the northern edge of Hanoi Old Quarter. It is Hanoi’s largest indoor market, offering a wide range of goods for instance: fresh vegetables, souvenirs, accessories, clothing, as well as electronic and household appliances.

Dong Xuan Market is worth to experience the local lifestyle. It has a bustling wet market section on the ground floor with seafood, meat, vegetables and the back section sells an array of pet and fresh flowers from all around of Vietnam. You can also find numerous stalls selling clothes, handbags, handicrafts, which are sold at wholesale price but quality stuff.
4. Hanoi Opera House

Hanoi Opera House is one of the most famous cultural and architectural monuments of Hanoi. It was constructed from 1901 to 1911 with the European architectural style under the Renaissance period with Italian-made marble floor, copper chandeliers and exquisite. In the past, the theater solely hosted performances by Western artists for French officials and wealthy Vietnamese. Nowadays, Hanoi Opera House is one of Hanoi’s cultural centers where art shows, concerts, dance performances and other events usually take place, with the scale ranging from national to international.
Even there are a variety of art events ranging from the traditional Vietnamese music to the more trendy pop music are performed here.
5. One Pillar Pagoda

The One Pillar Pagoda reflects the architectural spendour and is a historic Buddist temple in Hanoi. It is unique because it was built in only one pillar and is shaped lotus flower. It has the legendary story of the Emperor Ly Thai To of the Ly dynasty who required his servants to build in a style of a lotus emerging out of the water to honour the Bodhisattave Avalokiteshvara for giving him a babyboy as he wished for such a long time. You visit another very interesting free attraction in Hanoi city.
6. Hanoi Flag Tower
Hanoi Flag Tower is the symbol of Hanoi at the age of nearly 200. The construction began in 1805 and completed in 1812.

Flag Tower is one of  architecture works which still remains well today. Its image has been embedded in many remarkable historic events. The flag of Vietnam flew on the top of the Flag Tower for the first time in 1945, after The August Revolution’s success, and on October 10th, 1954- the capital Libration day; image of Flag Tower is printed on money paper issued firstly by the Bank of Vietnam.
Hanoi Flag Tower is 33m high and 41m high consisting of the flag pole. With original construction purpose as an observatory; it offers a breathtaking view.
7. Long Bien Bridge

Long Bien bridge can be in list of free attractions in Hanoi city. It is the historical witness symbolizing of courageous capital during the wars. It was constructed from 1989 to 1902 during French occupation of the country. It was bombed many items by air attacks by American army in 1967, 1972 and many spans of it were destroyed. The left ones still remain reminding us of an unforgettable past.

Long Bien Bridge is the best place to look at the sunrise or the sunset and taking nice photos of alluvial patch with full green tree. Many vendors and housewives still come here every afternoon for an open air market.
8. Hoan Kiem Lake

Many tourists and locals choose Hoan Kiem as a place to get away from the noise of the city. It is peaceful and quiet in the morning and is very romantic in the evening when all the light are on. It becomes symbol of Hanoi with the Ngoc Son temple in the middle of the lake crossing by The Huc Bridge or Rising Sun Bridge.
The legend of Hoan Kiem Lake is quite interesting for many tourists relating to the Golden tortoise.
9. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum

It is situated in Ba Dinh Square and is the place that the government of Vietnam keeps Ho Chi Minh's body known as Uncle Ho by local in a glass case in central of Hanoi. Tourists can visit for free for every morning except Monday and Friday morning. You normally need to wait in a long queue and it is recommended to wear formal dress to visit him. Anually from October to November, Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum will be closed for maintenance.
10. Hanoi Old Quarter

Hanoi Old Quarter offers the most crowded activities for tourists. It offers the rich food culture and a long history of 36 ancient streets of Hanoi. Streets packed with scooters, bicycles and cars  that make you walk around the street out and in all the time. It is very interesting to experience the  local style of Hanoian people.

column1: 9947,"[:en]What to see in Ho Chi Minh city ?[:]","[:en]<h2>

column2: Ho Chi Minh, a lively and dynamic city in the South of Vietnam which attracts million of visitors. Let Vietnamvisavisavoa.com be your guide in this fascinating city.
1. War Remnants Museum

The War Remnants Museum is very popular with Western tourists because it conveys the brutality of war and its civilian victims that not many museums can do well. It is interesting that many of the atrocities documented were well-publicized but rarely do Westerners hear the victims of US military action telling their own stories. It deserves to be in your top list of "What to see in Ho Chi Minh city ?"

The ground floor of the museum includes a collection of posters and photographs showing support for the antiwar movement internationally. You’ll  have the rare chance to see some of the experimental weapons used in the war, which were military secrets, such as the flechette, an artillery shell filled with thousands of tiny darts.
2. Ben Thanh Market

Ben Thanh market, the symbol of Ho Chi Minh city. Ben Thanh market itself and its surrounding streets are two of Saigon's liveliest areas.  You can find many things from common eatings, wearings used by the Saigonese. Even souvenir items can be found in equal abundance.
3. Cu Chi Tunnels

This remarkable tunnel is open to the public to understand more about Vietnam history. Another place for visiting in Ho Chi Minh city that tourists should highlight among other things in list of "What to see in Ho Chi Minh city ?". Even if you stay above ground, it’s still interesting experience learning about the regions ingenious and brave resistance activities. You will enhance vividly the knowledge what it must have been for soldiers who used to move around undetectedly by their enemies.
4. Reunification Palace

The Reunification Palace is a five-storey building with the basement housing a warren of tunnels, a war room and telecommunications centre. The Reunification Palace shows the world history books in 1975 when a Vietnamese Air Force flew an aircraft over the palace with an attempt to bomb it. Although no real damage was caused, this was a significant step towards the fall of Saigon and the ending of the Vietnamese War. It is one of the historical witness that is in pride of all Vietnamese people and to encourage young generations from preserving this palace well.

column3: One of historical witnesses for Vietnam war left deep imprints, big pride for Vietnamese people. What to see in Ho Chi Minh city ?

column2: 5. Notre Dame Cathedral

Saigon Notre Dame Cathedral was built in the late 1880s by French colonists and is one of the few remaining strongholds of Catholicism in the largely Buddhist Vietnam. It is almost 60 metres in height, is distinctive neo-Romanesque features includes the all-red brick façade, stained glass windows, two bell towers containing six bronze bells that still ring to this day, and a peaceful garden setting in the middle of downtown Ho Chi Minh City District 1. This is also an ideal place to selfie!
6.  Cao Dai Temple

It worshippers for world peace and harmony with beliefs steeped in a number of world religions. Followers must obey the five virtues of Confucianism – humanity, obligation, civility, knowledge and reliability and have belief in the Buddhist principles of rebirth and karma.

You should realize that watching Caodiasts pray is one of the highlights when visiting the temple because  they dress in long flowing robes of white for lay followers, yellow, blue or red for priests whilst bishops have the Divine Eye embroidered on their headpieces.

During the worship, men are seated on the right and women on the left with all devotees seated in ordered rows. The building is a combination of Neo-Gothic, Baroque and Oriental design and is very ornately decorated including dragon wrapped pillars, seven-headed cobras and ceilings of sky blue.

column1: 9964,"[:en]Ideal places for retiring in Vietnam[:]","[:en]

column2: Vietnam is “one of the most affordable places in the world to retire for an interesting and comfortable life” said Peddicord (Investpedia.com).

After many years of working hard, it is time to find a good place to enjoy the rest of your life without working. Let discover places for retiring in Vietnam. They are: Da Nang, Vung Tau , Nha Trang and Da Lat.
Da Nang

This is known as the most worth-living city in Vietnam. According to Peddicord, it is Vietnam’s best golf course and it is favored with very long, beautiful beach, especially it is not a crowded and noisy city. It is a city of a million people dotted with new skyscrapers and is a place of wide, easily-traveled roads and wide sidewalks, too. Da Nang finds it easier to walk free of bikes and especially motorbikes.  The coastline is utterly beautiful and very clean with lifeguards.

It has one of the major port cities in Vietnam and the biggest city on the South Central Coast of Vietnam. It is a great place to retire based on its many available and inexpensive rentals. For example, a fully furnished two bedroom, two-bath luxury condo in the Indochina Riverside Tower complex is about $700/month. It is located in a prime spot near the riverside promenade in central Da Nang.
Nha Trang

Nha Trang is one of the lowest costs of living of any city in Southeast Asia or the world with monthly budget for about $650. The city has been actively welcoming westerners to its shores since the 1920s and has a foreigner-friendly network that expats can feel comfortable to retire in Vietnam. Life here can be as adventurous or as laid-back. Nha Trang has beautiful beach and ocean. The bay offers water diversion and  the mountain and rural landscapes lures exploration.

This is about 275 miles Northeast of Ho Chi Minh city. It is a popular Vietnamese vacation destination not only for locals but also international tourists with more than four miles of beaches. The locals here are industrious, open and so friendly. The food, especially seafood is delicious and various with the comfortable weather year-round without extreme variations. Nha Trang has a long dry season, which runs from January to August.
Da Lat

Da Lat is quite different kind of place with its big advantage in hot weather. It is a mountain resort complete with pine trees. You can rent an apartment in Da Lat for around $300/month. It is very famous for its flowers and flower festival is held here in December and January yearly. It is better to live in the outskirts, no matter how tempting the center is, with its thriving seafood market, the moon-shaped Xuan Huong Lake and charming French architecture from colonial days. All of best, its outskirts are prettier than the center of town with better views, which is ideal for retiring in Vietnam.
Vung Tau

Vung Tau was Vietnam’s first established seaside resort. It has 2,021 miles of coastline, which is an impressive distinction. It is now increasingly sought out by expat retirees. It is attractive because it has very low cost of living for the good life in this pretty beach resort town. It is not only the most affordable location but it is also one of the most affordable places in the world to live well. With a budget of $3,000 per month, you could enjoy a legitimately luxury-standard lifestyle.

One more thing is that Vung Tau owns the best infrastructure in Vietnam. The roads are in good condition and there are several new divided highways, a rarity in this country. Parks are clean, shady and pleasant and some of them are well-maintained exercise equipment available at no charge for anyone’s use.

The air is clean, and a constant cross-breeze cools the warm temperatures. It is an ideal condition for surfing, parasailing and parasurfing. Furnished condominiums start at about $600 per month with an upper range of around $1,000 monthly for newer units with ocean views.
You can start thinking about retiring in Vietnam now  and then apply online for Vietnam visa via http://vietnamvisavoa.com/apply-online/ to enjoy your retirement.

column1: 9990,"[:en]Son Doong Cave: World’s largest cave [:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: Have you heard about the World largest cave in the world ? Son Doong Cave is the World’s largest cave discovered in 2009. Do you know that the heaven favors Vietnam this precious cave ? Then, why not packing your luggage to visit this wonder ?

Son Doong cave is world's largest cave, located in Quang Binh province, Vietnam, is found by a local man named Ho Khanh in 1991 and was recently discovered in 2009 by British cavers, led by Howard Limbert. It is over 5.5 miles long, 650ft wide and 500ft tall and has a jungle and river and could fit a 40-story-skyscrapper within its walls. It is five times the size of Malaysia’s Deer Cave.

The name "Son Doong" cave means "mountain river cave". You must be surprised that it was created 2 - 5 million years ago by river water eroding away the limestone underneath the mountain. When the limestone was weak, the roof of the cave collapsed centuries ago and allowing a lush jungle to take root and creating huge skylights.
Saudi Arabia Crown Prince discovers Son Doong Cave in 2014  and this is the first person who has successfully conquered the world’s largest cave Son Doong.

On tours, visitors rappel 80 meters to enter Son Doong. They must afford with a spare of $3,000 US to take this tour and many tourists have booked tour many months before to get to the cave mouth. Son Doong Cave is an adventure in itself. The cave is made up of a network of at least 150 individual caves, has its own lake, river and jungle. The approach to the Son Doong Cave in Vietnam is a treacherous 36-hour journey through dense jungle. The British tourist Simon Dunne said the absolute silence in the cave was unforgettable. It seems to take 20 minute walk away  but actually it takes 2 hours to reach. The darkness confuses your sense of depth, especially when you are given a rare glimpse of light, too.

There are more and more foreigners choose to live in Vietnam. In order to adaft to the life here, it is highly recommended that you should know Vietnamese. Any expats in Vietnam who would like to learn Vietnamese find it hard to master to learn by themselves. If you want to learn more you really need to invest a bit of time and money on Vietnamese classes for expats in Vietnam.
Why to find Vietnamese classes for expats?

Having some Vietnamese language skills certainly makes living in Vietnam much easier as Vietnamese classes focus on vocabulary and conversational skills that they can be related to everyday situations to encounter when living and working in Vietnam. It is especially useful for communicating with local people and Vietnamese colleagues when they work and teach English, for example. Of course, language is the root of culture when it comes to living in Vietnam. Moreover, participating in a class, you are guided well when directly communicate with Vietnamese so you can improve faster.

Only few universities offer Vietnamese class for expats and most just at the elementary level and at very restricted time. So expats should find down private teachers or tutors in order to learn Vietnamese effectively. Sometimes, there are risks when some teachers and tutors may have limited experience in teaching Vietnamese to foreigners as Vietnamese is a difficult language for foreigners to learn and especially the tones.
You might see some Vietnamese teaching centers that you might consider from several foreigners’ experience.
1. 123Vietnamese Center

This center has trained thousands of students from Korea, China, Japan, America, England, Australia, France, Thailand, Laos, Cambodia etc. The teachers are skillful, experienced and enthusiastic. They are lecturers from Hanoi University of Education and University of Languages and International Studies. Another strength of the center is that it offers flexible class in different schedule and the teachers can visit company worksites to conduct classes.
2. Saigon Language School
This center offers learners with elementary, intermediate and advanced course as regularly. Besides, it also offers special programs for tourist, business and private courses.
3. Faculty of Vietnamese Studies and Language at Hanoi National University of Education

A suitable choice for foreigners with expectation for the university's admission standards and who have time and flexibility to follow a fixed class schedule. In addition, the Hanoi National Universtiy of Education also offers students classes in Vietnamese culture and history.

Many native Vietnamese speakers can speak, read and write Vietnamese very well but not all are skilled in teaching Vietnamese as a foreign language. Qualified teachers will use specialized methods to help students to progress quickly and to guide students to advanced levels. Therefore, it is essential that the foreign students find a qualified teacher.

column1: 10027,"[:en]Volunteer jobs in Vietnam for foreigners[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: Volunteer jobs in Vietnam for foreigners are quite limited in Vietnam since there are so many professional development staff based here.
Here is the list for you to consider which organization that you can do volunteer.

The non-profitable organizations are good sources for doing volunteering such as the Service Civil International with activities including to the Friendship Village, which is established to help victims of Agent Orange. Or the Center for Sustainable Development Studies addresses development problems through international exchange and non-formal education.
Other organizations that you can work for such as:
KOTO (www.koto.com.au) helps street children with their career opportunities in its restaurants in Hanoi or HCMC. You can work there with a compulsory three-month minimum commitment.

International organizations offers positions in Vietnam including Voluntary Service Overseas in the UK, Australian Volunteers International, Volunteer Service Abroad in New Zealand, the UN’s volunteer program and US-based International Volunteer HQ. All have wide ranges of volunteer projects in Hanoi.
During the short time in Vietnam, you might expect to get a job, here are some jobs you can check.

There are some tourism services such as restaurants, bar, night club, especially for western-owned bars and restaurants in touristy places. This is the opportunity for you to work without paperwork and get money in hand. You know that dive schools and adventure sports specialists will always need instructors, then you can consider and you are easily get this kind of high paid job. However, most travelers take the main work opportunities of teaching English as a foreign language.

English is by far the most popular foreign language for Vietnamese students. Especially when English is one of three compulsory subjects at schools. The high demand for learning English can be found in big cities such as Hanoi, Nha Trang and Ho Chi Minh city.  The salary is usually higher in big cities than in the provinces. Normarlly, you can earn from US$ 15 to US$ 20 per hour and home tutoring from US$ 15 to US$ 25 per hour.
There are also some demand for Mandarin and French. In addition, government-run universities in Vietnam also hire some foreign teachers.

You can spend  more time in Vietnam than a vacation limitation after applying for Vietnam visa on arrival of tourist visa with vietnamvisavoa.com, then you can stay more during your time of tourist visa expired date or exist Vietnam with a new visa or even make visa extension.
