Thanks to policies to promote tourism, custom regulations in Vietnam nowadays are getting much simpler than ever before. However, as a wise traveler, you should pay attention to basic information about Vietnam custom regulations:
1. Requirement documents

To enter Vietnam, your passport must be valid for six months upon arrival in Vietnam. And you must apply for a Vietnam visa if you are not in the visa exemption list. Visa procedure can be simple but fast-changing. From 1st July 2016, 5 European countries continue to get Vietnam 15-day visa exemption for another year including UK, Italy, Spanish, French and Germany. The government has relaxed visa exemption rules to traffic them visiting Vietnam for tourism development and reduced visa fees.

For those who must get Vietnam visa as a tourist could apply for 1 month or 3 months single/ multiple entry visas. There are two methods of applying for a Vietnam visa: Getting Vietnam visa online done via visa agents or getting visa at Vietnamese Embassy/ Consulate. All most travelers choose to arrive in Vietnam by air, since it is more convenient and they could get Vietnam visa on arrival just by submitting Vietnam visa request online before heading to Vietnam. All you need to do is to fill out an online application form at vietnamvisavoa.com and pay for service fee. After one or two working days, you'll then receive by email an approval visa letter signed by Vietnamese Immigration. You just need to print out and bring along to Vietnam International airports where your Vietnam visa will be stamped on your passport.

You can also obtain visas at Vietnam Embassy/ Consulate around the world. However, please note that fees are normally higher than getting visa online via a visa agent and depending upon the country, the procedure and fee would not be the same.
2. Goods and Products:
You are able to bring the maximum amount of the followings; otherwise, it is mandatory to declare and pay import taxes:
Duty Free:
Cigarettes: 400
Cigars: 100
Tobacco: 100 gram
Liquor: 1.5 liters
Perfume and jewellery for personal use
Souvenirs and gift items valued at not more than US$ 300
Materials Under Declaration
There are no restrictions on the amount of currency, gold, precious metals and stones; however, you have to declare on the customs forms provided that your luggage includes:
Declare if you bring:
Foreign currency: in excess of US$ 5,000
Vietnam Dong: in excess of VND15.000.000
Gold: in excess of 300gr
Gold and jewellery not for personal use
Video tapes, CDs: CDs and tapes are often kept for screening and returned to you after a few days
Banned Materials
Things below should be excluded from your luggage:
<li>

column3: Weapon,ammunition, explosives and inflammable objects

column2: <li>

column3: Military technical equipment; drugs, opium and other narcotics

column2: <li>

column3: Anti-government literature; pornographic literature, etc.

column2: On top of this; antiques, some types of precious stones, wild animals, rare and precious plants listed in Vietnam’s red-book could not be exported.

Please note that this is only a brief summary about Vietnam custom regulations and they are subjected to change over the time. Therefore, it is recommended to update the information. It is always useful to update Vietnamese custom regulations at: www.customs.gov.vn/English/Lists/CustomsFormalities/Traveller.aspx.
For further information about Vietnam custom regulations, please contact us via support@vietnamvisavoa.com or hotline: +84.941279289.

column1: 10047,"[:en]Best backpackers hostels in Hanoi city[:]","[:en]

column2: For many tourists, when travelling, they must spend their nights in comfortable and luxurious rooms however for many other tourists especially backpackers, they must save as much as they can and what they look for is a room with good security and good enough to sleep after long day outside. If you are visiting Hanoi and like to find good hostels for your holiday stay at affordable prices then you should not miss this post. Here is a list of best backpackers hostels in Hanoi city that you can check based on the ranks in the TripAdvisor.com in 2016.
1. Vietnam Backpacker Hostels-Downtown
Add: 9 Ma May str, Hoan Kiem, Hanoi, Vietnam.

This hostel is in list of good hostel in Hanoi for anybody looking for a good time. It has an on-site bar which travelers from all over the world who are looking to meet fellow travelers. The staff is friendly, the beds are comfortable, and the amenities are plentiful. Breakfast is included as is WiFi internet access, linens, towels, and more.
The reception area is open 24 hours a day. Other amenities include free breakfast, plenty of common space, an outdoor terrace, and security lockers.
2. Hanoi Backpackers Hostel- The Original
Add: 48 Ngo Huyen lane, Hoan Kiem, Hanoi, Vietnam

It offers a hassle free airport transfer. Guests can choose between female dorms, mixed dorm and double suites. The staff are there to help with any advice that you need. It also get complementary walking tour of the Old quarter and the Cathedral area everday from 10am.
3. Riverside Palace Hostel
Add: No 14 Tho Xuong Lane, Au Trieu str, Hoan Kiem,Hanoi

The atmosphere is comfortable, relaxing and inviting to all travelers. The room is equipped with a mini refrigerator, complimentary toiletries, cable television on a LCD screen, a private computer. Wifi connection, air conditioning and noise canceling glass windows.
4. Hanoi Brother Inn
Add: No 21 Bat Dan str, Hoan Kiem, Hanoi, Vietnam
Hanoi Brother Inn, a hostel in Hanoi offers with most competitive prices with young, friendly and easy-going people with experience in hospitality. It is situated in the heart of Hanoi’s Old Quarter.
5. Funky Jungle Hostel
Add: No 73 Ma May str, Hoan Kiem, Hanoi

It is on the Ma May street that you can find the ultimate comfort with top quality beds, pillows and linen, gaming room, bar and lounge. Friendly staff are helpful for you with everything you need and answer any questions you may have about Vietnam.
6. Hanoi Traveller Hostel
Add: No 11 Hang Manh str, Hoan Kiem, Hanoi

You feel cozy, comfort and accommodating, we offer Vietnamese cultural style decorated. Internet with computer at lobby and hotel-wide WIFI coverage ensure effortless connectivity for entertainment, family contact, and work.
7. Hanoi Rock Hostel
Add: 54 Hang Duong Street, Old Quarter | Hoan Kiem district, Hanoi, Vietnam
8. Littel Hanoi Hostel
Add: 32 Le Thai To Street | Hoan Kiem, Hanoi, Vietnam

It is locted in a quite alley, right across the street from Hoan Kiem Lake at the heart of Hanoi. Guests choose single, double or twin rooms. All classice wooden furniture, own private modern bathrooms and air conditioning.
9. Chien Hostel
Add:12- 14 Au Trieu, Hang Trong Ward, Hoan Kiem District, Hanoi,Vietnam

It has 12 en-suite exclusive guest rooms offering cosmopolitan elegance and comfort to suit all needs from business to family, to leisure and adventure. It boasts extremely spacious rooms, offering panoramic views from window, brand new western style bathrooms and and beds.
10. See you at Lily's
Add:16 Ngo Huyen , Hoan Kiem District, Hanoi, Vietnam

Another hostel in Hanoi named See you at Lily's, in the very heart of the charming hostoric Hanoi Old Quarter offers guests a perfect retreat from the vibrant and buzzing streets. It has two newly fitted mixed dorm rooms with large selection of foods for breakfast, mianly western style.
Further information about best backpackers hostels in Hanoi city, do not forget to contact us at: support@vietnamvisavoa.com
With regard drinking in Vietnam , you will feel easily to take iced tea and sugar cane juice, drinking on the pavement or in the park while for many countries, it is illegal.

For this part 1, you are guided to know more about roadside drinking in Hanoi, Vietnam.Throughout Hanoi streets or in Ho Chi Minh city, the streets and parks are alive with food and drink stalls. People just drop in and take a sip of fresh water, talk with friends on a tiny stall.
In summer, Tra (tea) is most common, especially for its iced taste. It is just no more than 10,000VND a glass.

For young people, lemon iced tea is very popular in combination of lemon juice sweetened with sugar and served over ice. It is very refreshing and delicious for super hot day around the St Joseph’s Cathedral. Most streets of Vietnam have one drink stall at least. Drink stall are situated under the shade of the rows of trees. Sugar cane juice is a kind of refreshing option, too. It is an old-fahsioned looking green magles which squeeze all the goodness out of the sugar cane and into glass. It is easy to take it away well when it is served in a sealed plastic bag with a straw, perfect for on the move sipping. Price for sugar can juice is under 20,000VND.

Besides, on the coffee street, Nguyen Huu Huan street, it is the heaven of coffee shops that are the destinations for most Hanoians in the evening. Most coffee shops are crowded with people and even lively music. With free wi-fi, they are ideal place for being relaxed and surfing net to connect with friends.

We also could not miss the beer corner, Ta Hien street with many foreigners , tourists and young locals. Sitting down and drink Bia Hơi seems to be a common habit of most Vietnamese young people and it is even more popular in the Night Market on weekends. Other drink stalls could be scattered around Hanoi and favour a lot of Vietnamese men as daily rountine. Places men stay away from working at the office in the burning days.
Further information regarding to drinking in Vietnam, please contact us via vietnamvisavoa.com.

Beside the roadside drinking in Hanoi, this article will show you about one place in Hanoi, it is Xuan Dieu, which is famous for real drinking with live music, dancing, drinking or a more laidback vibe.

The first location is No 88 Lounge, which is opened in 2013 and is an impressive four-storey space boasting exposed concrete and brick, artworks and regal striped furniture. Drinks are various but mostly wine, with bottles adorning the walls and some imported beers such as Duval and Leffe. You can freely sit from comfy sofas to dining style. The views and atmosphere are all good with something relaxing; even it does get busy on the weekends or when they sometimes host an event.
Another place is Tay Tap,  and spreads over three floors, including a small roof terrace with good views of the lake. It is turned on with live music. It’s open from 16:00 until late.
The Light is a small place back towards Saint Honore and attracts a younger crowd than Tay Tap.
The Red River Tea Rooms. The place  is near Diue’s cuisine. It serves with cold beer and keen service await although it’s usually quieter than places like Tay Tap and 88 Lounge.

The House of Son Tinh is often quiet and its back room houses a huge screen serving for big sports events and football matches.  It’s one of our favorite places to sit for a few street side beers and, of course, serves Son Tinh liquor by the glass, bottle or in a cocktail.

Madake, which hosts DJs most weekends as well as occasional events is near the other end of the street. Upstairs is a bar area, a Thai restaurant, and down some rickety steps is a courtyard area and a small inside room where the bands and DJs play
Hanoi Rock City, another music venue, is around the corner on To Ngoc Van.

Airlines in Vietnam have been more various and provide ever-changing quality for travelers to Vietnam.

Vietnam boasts numerous land crossings and international flight connections to Australia, Cambodia, China, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Laos, Malaysia, Russia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand and the USA. You can also enter Vietnam by boat from Cambodia and by train from China.

In case you are traveling by land or sea to Vietnam. You are required to get Vietnam visa prior to your trip at Vietnam Embassy/ Consulate. For Vietnam visa online or Vietnam visa on arrival, it is applicable for travelers taking airplane to Vietnam international airports only. You can easily submit a visa form online at: http://vietnamvisavoa.com/apply-online/ You pay for service fee to get a pre-approval letter online and then take a flight to Vietnam. You will get your stamped visa at Vietnam International airport. There are 4 international airports of Vietnam: Noi Bai Airport in Hanoi, Tan Son Nhat Airport in Ho Chi Minh city, Da Nang Airport in Da Nang and Cam Ranh Airport in Nha Trang city. Please do remember that, if you have connecting flights between these airports, you are required to get stamped visa at the first arrival airport no matter how long you are there. For example, you fly to Noi Bai airport first and take a connecting flight to Ho Chi Minh, you must get visa at Noi Bai airport. Sometimes, you could clear the procedure quickly but it is recommended to get at least 3 hours between 2 flights to avoid rushing.
Currently, there are 7 registered airlines in Vietnam: Vietnam Airlines, Jetstar Pacific, Air Mekong, VASCO, Indochina Airlines, VietJetStar adn Viet Star Airlines.

Vietnam Airlines is Vietnam's national carrier and is the main operator on most routes both within Vietnam and from Vietnam to other international destinations. Its fleet is painted blue with a yellow lotus at its tail. Vietnam Airlines is most recommended for your comfortable flights though the fare is normally more expensive.
Vietjet Air is the second domestic carrier with a more limited network. This carrier aims at providing cheap airfares to users.

Jetstar Pacific Airlines also have more than 4.000 flights to more than 75 destinations in the world such as Australia, New Zealand etc. It also frequent flights among Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh city and Da Nang. Jetstar is also known as a cheap airfare provider but be aware of being delayed or cancelled. It happens almost every day in almost flights.

Air Mekong is the latest addition to the small collection of airlines in Vietnam. Air Mekong is based in Phu Quoc and offers competitive ticket fare. Its operating routes are denser in the South and Central Highland of Vietnam. There are flights connecting Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh city with Phu Quoc and Con Dao Islands and with Vietnam Central Highland area.
Further information about Airlines in Vietnam, please contact us via support@vietnamvisavoa.com

While travelling around Vietnam, many travellers would love to travel by train in order to appreciate the wonderful beauty of Vietnam through view from the trains. This is a rare chance which you can not have if you take flights or buses.

All of Vietnam railway stations  are owned and primarily operated by the state-owned Vietnam Railways. Its primary route is the 1,726 Km single track North-South Railway line running between Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh city.

The railway links from Hanoi to Lao Cai, Sapa was originally built by the French administration of Indochina in the early 20th century as part of an international railway link between Hai Phong and Chinese city of Kunming.
Hanoi to Dong Dang route is the rail links between Vietnam and China and it is the most popular route between these 2 destinations.
Besides, Hanoi to Hai Phong route, Hanoi to Quan Trieu, Kep to Ha Long and Kep to Luu Xa are lesser.

Hanoi train station, which used to serve the French Government in transporting coal and other minerals to Haiphong port and from there to deliver to France, now becomes one of the most important stations of Vietnam Railway system. There are 2 areas: Area A for the Thong Nhat railways, from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh; area B located in Tran Quy Cap street for others railways to North highlands like Lao Cai/ Sapa. It is now modern and upgraded with free Wifi and railroad infrastructure are frequently maintained.
Hue train station

Hue Train Station is situated on the straight railways from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh City. It was used to be a historical place, where patriots connected together through the secret area around the station, carried thousands of young people to the South to fight for country liberation. Nowadays, Hue Train Station, based in Bui Thi Xuan Street, is one of the most important station of the country, a big transit point of the Center of Vietnam.
Ho Chi Minh city train station

Ho Chi Minh city train station is located in District 3, the most crucial economic and social center in the South of Vietnam. Its location makes this place an important node between the North –South railways system of Vietnam. At present, Ho Chi Minh train station is also the most modern train station in the South of Vietnam, with high quality facility and well equipped waiting room.
Contact us via support@vietnamvisavoa.com or skype: vietnamvisa.VOA for further details about Vietnam railway stations.

Once expats plan to settle their life in Vietnam, it is crucial that they must find a place for a comfortable living but affordable budget. Vietnam do offers a wide range of rental options depends upon the facility, furniture in the house and its location. Basically, there are 3 main types of urban housing that expats should consider:
Types of rental
Row house or street house:

In common, there are 4 floors in this of kind of house and it is true that its length is much longer than its width. These houses are located on the main streets or alley and are situated side by side. Practically, it is used mostly for business: shops, banks, restaurants…. If you intend to get it for staying, do consider about the noise from the streets.
Detached house:

This type of house is on a plot of land and almost has a private driveway with surrounding garden and boundary fence. Normally, there are 4 floors and facades that are open to the surrounding environment. Unfortunately, finding this house in densely populated cities like Ha Noi and Ho Chi Minh seems to be a tough task.
Apartment:

It is a room inside a building with two or more levels with pathways, staircases and an infrastructure system that is used by many households. As a result of huge immigration and high demand from locals and foreigners, living in apartment is considered to be the best option. There are more and more buildings are builted over the years with different standard from the luxury ones to the normal ones. When you choose to rent an apartment, there are 2 options: serviced or normal. Serviced apartments are furnished, and generally offer amenities such as a reception desk, gym, restaurants and housekeeping. On the other hand, normal apartments will save you much money, but you have to deal with the landlord and establish a connection to the utilities yourself. A normal apartment is probably the best option for a long stay for those who lives a simple life.
How much does it cost?
Estimated pricing
Houses: Between US$800 and US$ 2,500 a month.
Serviced apartments: Between US$1,000 and US$3,000 a month.
Normal apartments: Between US$400 and US$1,000 a month.
Room: Between US$ 200 to US$ 400
Please consider these prices as an estimation ONLY, as housing prices vary from city to city and from neighborhood to neighborhood.
How to find accommodation in Vietnam?
Getting refferal from your friends or other foreigners, search on rental groups on Facebook or Expat groups. Besides, there are available websites for renting in Vietnam as below:
vietnam.craigslist.org/
www.izproperty.com/
HousingInteractive Vietnam
Don’t forget to apply for Vietnam visa for your new adventure in Vietnam!

Expats would like to know about renting apartment cost in Hanoi should consider its prices depending on the areas which are closer or farther to the centre with most convenient environment, security and traffic.
Rental apartments or rental houses or even rental villas in Hanoi is quite popular in some main inner districts such as Tay Ho, Ba Dinh, Hoan Kiem, Hai Ba Trung.

For rental apartment cost in Hanoi, it is normally for apartments in big buiding near the city centre for instance: Times City, Royal city, Lotte Hanoi, Keangnam Tower etc. the price for one apartment could be from $1,000/month or more.
Other apartment in smaller buildings with quite spacious ones could be from $500/month

According to update news based on 860 entries in the past 18 months from 77 different contributors in July, 2016 (numbeo.com), renting apartment cost in Hanoi for one bedroom in city centre is nearly 10 million VND per month; 6 million VND for apartment with one bedroom outside the centre; approximately 23 million VND for an apartment with 3 bedrooms in city centre and nearly 12 million VND for an apartment with 3 bedrooms outside of centre on average. More details could be found in the links below"

Nightlife is not to be missed when you travel to touristic city like Hanoi. Let Vietnamvisavoa.com gives you a list of bars in Hanoi so that you could have superb nights during your holiday.
1. King pirates pub

This is the place that offers tourists an ocean full of beverages and the friendliest crew on the high seas. The pub features a relaxing laid back atmosphere in which one can enjoy company of an international flavor. Do enjoy a bounty of good drink in the heart of Hoan Kiem Lake!
2. Le Pub Hanoi

This attracts international clients with its friendly vibe, live music, stylish décor, extensive drinks list, and attractive promotions. The tavern-like establishment is also fitted with a rear courtyard, street-facing terrace, and plenty of TV screens, making it a great place to catch up with the latest sports matches. Le Pub Hanoi serves imported wines, beers, cocktails, and liqueurs at reasonable prices while bar snacks range from nachos and pizzas to Vietnamese spring rolls.
Every Thursday, ladies get to enjoy free cocktails all night long and ice cold beers from 19:30 till 20:30. Don’t forget to take this chance to “attract” sexy ladies.
3. Minh‘s Jazz club

This is a legendary evening spot in Hanoi Old Quarter, especially for jazz lovers who are jazz fans to catch live performances by some of the finest musicians in the city. The establishment features minimal décor, cosy seating, efficient service, and an extensive food-and-beverages menu. Open all day, patrons can enjoy an impressive line-up of local and international acts performing between 21:00 and 23:30 every night.
4. Fat Cat Bar

This bar is set up in a quite small area however it shows a very good combination, unique decoration between the style of modern, noisy bar and a quite lounge. This creates a very comfortable atmosphere and so attractive for foreigners. They can sit down in the bar or enjoy nature by sitting outside, sipping some local beer and hang out with other friends in a very relaxing way.
5. Temple bar

Opened more than a year ago, it’s one of the survivors, but its clientele has changed: once the after hours place to be for backpackers, with a good mix of local and foreign trade, it’s now predominantly a locals’ haunt. Not that this should stop you going; if you like your bars crowded, dark and heaving to the sounds of drum and base,  dance music, you might have found your place.
6. Press Club Hanoi

It takes just a five-minute stroll from Hanoi Opera House to enjoy a well-known place for its excellent service and sophisticated setting. Attracting a more affluent clientele, the gentleman’s club-style bar serves excellent wines, champagnes, and cocktails as well gourmet western delicacies while the spacious terrace offers great views of Hoan Kiem Lake and downtown of Hanoi city.
You can also enjoy live rock music from Thursday to Sunday and a special buy-one-get-one-free deal on select drinks every Thursday.
7. Amazon Bar

It is a bar with seatings and a small balcony on the first floor, and it is a more of a nightclub feel upstairs— its darker and louder, with regular DJs. Both places attract a local and foreign crowd.
8. Hair of the dog

Hair of the Dog was on Hang Giay but rumour has it that it got shut down after too many late night police raids and it’s now re-opened on Ma May, in the building previously occupied by the short-lived Bucket Bar. Downstairs there’s a DJ, dance floor and busy bar, and upstairs is a bit quieter, with an area given over to beanbags and cushions: perfect for enjoying shisha.
9. Dragonfly Lounge bar
It’s dirty, crowded and full of youngsters, but if that’s your scene, go for it! The upstairs seated area is decent enough though.
10. Mao's Red Lounger

It is still popular with tourists and expats and is a more chilled scene with better music — in my personal opinion — than many of the nightclub and bar options I’ve previously mentioned. It’s a tiny place so if you don’t get a seat it can feel very cramped but there’s always room for one more.
Further information about Bars in Hanoi, just let us know at support@vietnamvisavoa.com and don’t forget to refer us vietnamvisavoa.com to your friends who are going to visit Vietnam.

column1: 10122,"[:en]Bars in Ho Chi Minh city[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: Bars in Ho Chi Minh city mostly are in downtown of district No.1. There are rooftop bars, high rolling casinos and smooth jazz bands. Let discover 10 most popular places below and we ensure  that tourists as well as expats will be pleased with the very best of nightlife experience.
1. Glow

Ho Chi Minh has one of the greatest collections of rooftop bars in the world. Glow has impressive rooftop bar with great music and a very relaxed atmosphere. Sit back with a cocktail and soak up the stunning view of Ho Chi Minh City from sunset until late into the night.
2. Chill Skybar
It has magic view and a beautiful crowd. It remains a great place for a night out. You just enjoy it with quite expensive charge.
3. Lush

It is an excellent place to meet foreigners and Vietnamese girls. It also attracts quite a lot of backpackers. Lush Nightclub is the premier nightclub in Ho Chi Minh. It is the place to see the beautiful of Saigon. The venue is kitted it out in an industrial chic style, with space to dance and an upstairs area with seating. Music ranges from house to hip hop and a bit of mainstream party pop depending on the night.
4. Sin Lounge

Sin Lounge is one of Ho Chi Minh’s favorite party venues for models, actresses and other local celebrities. Many of the patrons are Viet Kieu or Vietnamese overseas. This place usually has regular events such as guest DJs, bikini dancers or fashion shows.
5. Live Music Bar: Maxim’s

From smooth jazz to heavy rocks, you can probably choose a bar or club playing exactly that. Live music are fairly well spread out across the city so tourists should never be too far from. Especially, if you are staying in the popular areas of District 1 or 3, then you will be spoilt for choice. Maxim’s features jazzy or Latin tunes. Tourists can dance as well as practice with one of their professional dancers. It has friendly woman PRs, hostesses or waitresses.
6. Saigon Saigon Bar

The name of one of the bars in Ho Chi Minh city, Saigon Saigon Bar is another popular opt for tourists. It has a band from the Philippines singing Top 40 and famous songs. It can be quite but it is full on weekend nights.
7.  Apocalypse Now

It is one of the places that you can stay late over 3a.m. It is probably the best late night option though it is only open until 4a.m. Many pack backers, expats and prostitutes rock the dancefloor of this old-style club.
8. Last Call
It is a small place which is popular for expats that tourists can stay overnight and get much fun in the nighlife time.
9. Go 2 bar

One of the popular bars in Ho Chi Minh city is at the heart of Saigon’s backpacker district on De Tham street. Go 2 bar also offers services for late clubbers until 6 or 7 a.m. It has a lot of prostitutes and backpackers.
10. Phatty’s Sports Bar and Grill
It is one of the best choices to watch sports for expats. It is also an ideal place for socializing with fellow expats in Saigon.

column1: 10128,"[:en]Tips for traveling in Vietnam: Before the trip[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: Vietnam is a pretty small country but has been offered with a great deal of landscapes all around the country. Tips for travelling in Vietnam before the trip below will help you prepare well when coming to new culture and way of life.
1. Mindset

One of the first tips for traveling in Vietnam is that Vietnamese culture patterns are very different to what foreigners are familiar to. Vietnamese people are so curious and they tend to ask you personal questions, such as: How old are you ? Are you married ? What do you do ? How much do you earn ? in the first conversation, these questions dont aim at interfering your privacy but to show their care to you.
2. Visa issue

You have to care about the Vietnam visa carefully. Except for countries in Southeast Asia, most foreigners have to obtain a visa before entering Vietnam. You can get Vietnam visa at the Vietnam Embassy or Consulate by submitting your your passport, photos and fees or you can apply for Vietnam visa online. This is recommended  if you are far from Vietnam Embassy. More importatnt, it will save much of your time and cheaper price when you just connect to the Internet with online form. Please keep in mind that your passport needs to have at least 6 months validity and there is at least 1 blank visa page left.
3. Money and bargaining

Currency used in Vietnam is Vietnam Dong. One US dollar now equals about 22,600 Vietnam Dong. You can exchange money right at Vietnam airport when you just land or at banks, hotels or jewelry shops. The common place in Hanoi is Ha Trung Street.
Vietnam expense is quite cheap in comparison with other near by countries. Foods and drinks are various in range and price. You can eat a decent meal with just $2 or $3.

As for bargaining, except for fix prices in shops and supermarkets, you should bargain the price in the local market or night market. For clothes stuffs, it could be discount 50% of the first price offered.
4. Weather

Vietnam has typical monsoon weather with diverse weather pattern. It changes in every region from the North to the South, from the West to the East, from coasts to mountains. There is not really a best time to visit Vietnam, just the best time for each region.

The North suffers cold winter from November to March while the South is always hot. When you travel to Vietnam, depends upon which season and place you choose to travel, you make a suitable plan with range of activities. For people travelling from North to South in winter, you should bring all kinds of clothes including water-resistant shoes, raincoat, ponchos when go trekking or hiking in Vietnam.
5. Medication

In Vietnam, with the high humidity, malaria is the biggest concern in the summer. When you visit the country in summer, you had better to get advice from doctor about anti-malaria and anti-diarrhea drugs.

Vietnam is known as one of the most interesting country to visit not because of its beauty but also a rich culture and a reasonable cost of living. Below is the list of basic expense when you visit Vietnam.
Vietnam visa requirement

The first thing you need to prepare before travelling into Vietnam is Vietnam visa. You must check out if you need to get a visa to Vietnam or not. Except for citizens from Southeast Asia, Japan, Korea, some countries in North Europe are granted free entry to Vietnam, most other countries have to get Vietnam visa. You can either take it from Vietnamese Embassy/Consulate or getting Vietnam visa on arrival by submitting the visa form online through vietnamvisavoa.com You will get a Vietnam visa approval letter sent to your email and fly to Vietnam. At Vietnam Airport, you will get visa stamped on your passport. This is how Vietnam visa on arrival works.
Accommodation
Dormitory:  Not more $US 10/night, normally 8 travellers will share one room.
Cheap hotel: $ US 20: Normally, breakfast is not included in these hotels.
Standard hotel: $ US 30-$ US 50: A/C, Internet, Breakfast are included in room rate.
Boutique hotel: $US 60- $US 90: Rooms are bigger and modern equipments are available.
Luxury hotel: over $US 100: International brands like: Intercontinental, JW Marriot, Sheraton.....
Eating
Local meal, meal on the street : $ 1 US - $ US 2.5
Meal in a smart restaurant: From $20 US upwards
A gourmet restaurant: From $ US 40
Domestic flight

Vietnamese airlines have varied airfare in different times of year and different airlines. The popular ones are Vietnam airlines, Vietjetair, Jetstar. These brands vary in prices , service quality. Vietnam airlines are considered as the best one while the two others focus on low price for all most passengers.
Currency

Vietnam Dong is Vietnamese currency, they use big numbers in this country. One US dollar will be equal to around 22,000 Viennam Dong. You could exchange Vietnamese money when you get to airport, in banks, in hotels..... Normally, there is no cheating but tobe on the safe side, it is recommended to exchange money in banks. Some of thems are: Vietcombank, Vietinbank, ANZ. You also could withdraw money from ATMs and banks but remember that you only could collect Vietnam Dong. Any USD or foreign currency transactions are strictly controled.

column1: 10145,"[:en]What to buy when visiting Vietnam[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: Everyone tourist travelling to Vietnam is interested in a lot of amazing stuff that are specialties of Vietnam. You can consider these things deserved for what to buy when visiting Vietnam.
Conical hat

Conical hat is the symbol of Vietnamese women. It is always reminded in any international beauty shows or programs. It is  very common if you get one from the markets in Vietnam‘s old capital of Hue with a poem inscribed onto it. Its shape with the beauty of Vietnamese women is always attractive to tourists in everywhere.  You will feel something really peaceful, charming from Vietnam that you just wander lonely and pay for only one dollar only to keep great memory in Vietnam.
Snake Wine

You have heard about the snake village in Vietnam?  Snake wine is the sort of gift that can be very special and interesting for tourists. There is not much wine in it but the snake is infused in grain alcohol. Little snake wine to be treated to tourists is a specialty of Vietnam.  If you visit any houses in Vietnam, you will see that friendly grandparents always treat you with a little of it if you like. Snake wine is a specialty that we normally treat to special guests.
Ao Dai

What to buy when visiting Vietnam could not miss the Ao Dai. It is special clothing that most Vietnamese women wear as traditional clothes in most public events such as marriage, festivals, international programs or events. We try to advertise the image of Ao dai worldwide. With high quality of tight-fitting little silk, it will shape the beautiful body of any Vietnamese women. And of course, western girls will not forget to take one home and wow the boys there.
Coffee

Coffee, the special taste of Vietnam that you could not miss for what to buy when visiting Vietnam. Experiencing drinking iced coffee as locals in Vietnam will leave deep imprints in the mind of tourists. And if you are a coffee addict, coffee in Vietnam here is always the number one that you must buy. Especially, buying coffee beans is always considered common when visiting Hanoi.

Weasel coffee is very popular among other types of coffee. It is a kind of special coffee that is made by a group of weasels chucking up coffee beans. You will be very interested in its flavours because it is really nice and special.  You even don’t need to tell others about how it is made, just give them a try and they will fancy you.
Ho Chi Minh T-shirt

No one can forget the Uncle Ho, the Great Father of the Vietnam country. Despite the fact that he passed away for over 45 years, all of his stories and his traits are always in heart of Vietnamese people. You can buy a Ho Chi Minh T-shirt as great memory from Vietnam.
Watercolor painting

Wandering around streets of the Old Quarter in Hanoi, for example, you can easily notice with many watercolor paintings in many shops on the streets. They can be in the pictures by chance under the beautiful scenery of old streets. Picking up a painting of a pastoral scene of Vietnam’s stunning countryside is well worth doing. The artists are great copy masters that make their own things really well too.
So you can check the lists above for what to buy when visiting Vietnam well.

column1: 10153,"[:en]Shopping centers in Ho Chi Minh City[:]","[:en]<div style=""text-align: justify;"">

column2: Ho Chi Minh, the biggest and most dynamic city in Vietnam which is famous for many shopping centres. Below is the top 5 best shopping centers in Ho Chi Minh city that you should visit once you are in this city.
1. Vincom Center
It has become one of the biggest shopping centers in Ho Chi Minh City, at the center of the city at 72 Le Thanh Ton street.

Vincom is a shopping heaven for fashionista who would like to look for the latest trends of brand names. There are many famous brand names in Vincom such as Louis Vuiton, Armani, Jimmy Choo, Mango and other jewelry, make-up products, toys and shoes.

Vincom also has a dining area with a wide variety of foods. You can enjoy all kinds of cuisines from Vietnamese traditional food like Pho 24, Chinese food or typical Western fare like Popeyes or Breadtalk.
2. Parkson

It also has its noticeable architectural design and sells premium products only. Parkson has many famous brand names for clothes like Giordano, Esprit, shoes like Converse, Adidas, watches like Casio, Tiscot and make-up accessories like The Face Shop, Lancome etc.
You can enjoy with different kinds of food such as Japanese Kitchen, KFC, Lotteria.  It has it Megastar, which is one of the biggest and most modern movie theaters in Vietnam.
3. Diamond Plaza

Diamond Plaza is at 34 Le Duan street, District 1 near the Notre Dame Cathedral. It attracts many fashionista visiting every day. Diamond Plaza hosts many famous brand names for clothes, accessories, cosmetic and toys, etc.
4. Ben Thanh Market

Ben Thanh market is not a shopping mall but it is still a big shopping center in Ho Chi Minh City. Ben Thanh attracts many foreign visitors when coming to HCM city as tourists can buy many different kinds of goods every day with many beautiful clothes such as T-shirts, shorts, jeans, dresses; especially the traditional clothes of Vietnam: Ao Dai. It is like a wholesaler of the country.

The food section at Ben Thanh Market offers many different traditional kinds of food. Ben Thanh market has many kinds of authentic traditional Vietnamese foods. Many beautiful souvenirs can be found here.
5. Nowzone

Nowzone shopping mall is at 235 Nguyen Van Cu, District 1 and is popular visit destination to many people in Ho Chi Minh city. Comparing to other shopping malls like Vincom, Diamond or Parkson, Nowzone is suitable for average budget shoppers.

Nowzone offers many famous brand names of foreign fashion designers like Levi’s, Lee, Zara besides a good selection of Vietnamese brand names like Ninomax and Matanna. The 1st, 2nd and 3rd floor of Nowzone is for fashion, accessories and toys.

column1: 10161,"[:en]Requirements for being English teacher in Vietnam [:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: Working as an English teacher in Vietnam is quite common for a lot of expats. If you considering teaching English in Vietnam, you need to know requirements for being English teacher in Vietnam with the lists below.

1. There are schools that look to hire experienced certified teachers but some of thousands of schools and language institutes will hire teachers without prior experience, especially those who hold a TEFL certification , which  is recommended to have because it provides training to teach English as a foreign language  and you can earn by taking an accredited TEFL certification class. Vietnam  refers strongly to hire native English speakers and some countries even require citizenship from a native English speaking country to issue a work visa for teaching English.

2.Some schools in some countries will hire native English speakers with no training or teaching experience; however, if you want to teach English abroad professionally and do not an advanced degree in teaching English as a foreign language, it would be a huge benefit to take an accredited TEFL certification course.
3. A TEFL certification is not required for most volunteer opportunities to teach English abroad.
4. Those with a university degree, a TEFL certification and perhaps prior teaching experience will have more opportunities to gain employment as an English teacher.

For example, citizens of EU nations possessing excellent English skills, a university degree, a TEFL certification and perhaps prior teaching experience will find opportunities in many nations throughout Europe that will not be open to non-Europeans. Also, if through marriage or some other circumstance, a non-native speaker also holds a work or residency visa in a particular country, it will be far easier for them to get hired to teach English in that nation.
5. English speakers without a four-year degree can still gain professional English teaching jobs in dozens of countries around the world.

column1: 10165,"[:en]What to do in Phu Quoc island?[:]","[:en]

column2: There ares sights in Phu Quoc Island that tourists could not miss in a paradise of Vietnam.
1. Long Beach

It is one of the prettiest beaches on the island. It has the vast bulk of Phu Quoc’s hotels  is on Bai Truong, also known as Long Beach, a 20-plus kilometre stretch of yellow sand that runs down the central west coast of the island. In the dry season, it’s a placid pool with gentle waves and is the liveliest beach on the island. It is the paradise that you get 100% body relaxing with accommodation and spots to play, laze and eat seafood with your feet in the sand.
2. An Thoi Beach
It is just off the southern tip of Phu Quoc. It’s a fine area for sightseeing, fishing, swimming and snorkelling.

Other islands here include Hon Dua (Coconut Island), Hon Roi (Lamp Island), Hon Vang (Echo Island), Hon May Rut (Cold Cloud Island), the Hon Dams (Shadow Islands), Chan Qui (Yellow Tortoise) and Hon Mong Tay (Short Gun Island).
3. Fish Sauce Factory

Phu Quoc has been famous for long time  thanks to its famous fish sauce. Meanwhile, the distillery of Nuoc Mam Hung Thanh is the largest of Phu Quoc’s fish-sauce makers. Most of the sauce produced is exported to the land for huge domestic consumption, though an impressive amount finds its way abroad to kitchens in Japan, North America and Europe.
4. Phu Quoc National Park

The park is forested and the trees and adjoining marine environment enjoy official protection. This is the last large stand of forest in the south, and the park was declared a Unesco Biosphere Reserve in 2010
5. Sao Beach

It is considered Phu Quoc’s best island with photogenic white sand and turquoise water.  It has picture-perfect white sand. The delightful curve of beautiful Sao Beach bends out alongside a sea of mineral-water clarity just a few kilometres from An Thoi, the main shipping port at the southern tip of the island.  Beside, there are a couple of beachfront restaurants, where you can settle into a deckchair or enjoy watersports.
6. Duong Dong

It is the island’s main town.A chief fishing port on the central west coast is a tangle of budget hotels catering to domestic tourists, streetside stalls, bars and shops. The old bridge in town is a great to photograph the island’s scruffy fishing fleet crammed into the narrow channel, and the filthy, bustling produce market makes for an interesting stroll.
7. Coi Nguon Museum
This museum is covered with a boatful of barnacle-encrusted ceramics, oddly compelling, shell-covered furniture and a small room devoted to the island prison.
8. Tranh Stream

The most accessible of these is Suoi Tranh to look for the entrance sign and concrete tree from the Duong Dong–Vong Beach road. From the ticket counter it’s a 10-minute walk through the forest to the falls.
9. Da Ban Stream
Suoi Da Ban is a white-water creek tumbling across some attractive

column1: 10175,"[:en]How to get to Phu Quoc island?[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align: justify;"">

column2: - How to get to Phu Quoc island?
- There are 2 ways in getting to Phu Quoc island: by air and by sea.
With regarding to traveling by air, you need to know which flights to Phu Quoc, including timetable, booking information and flight times.
Getting visas and customs for tourists also need to be taken care well as getting visa to Phu Quoc has different policy from getting Vietnam visa in general set up by the Immigration Department.

The services are daily flights to Can Tho (50 minutes), three daily to Hanoi (2½ hours), 15 daily to HCMC (one hour), daily flights in season to Rach Gia (30 minutes), and two flights per week to Singapore (1¾ hours).

Phu Quoc International Airport is 10km southeast of Duong Dong.  All flights land at the Phu Quoc International Airport in Duong Dong Town.  A new route connecting Hai Phong to Phu Quoc has been added by VietjetAir as of May 2016 with four round-trip flights per week on Tuesday, Thursday, Saturday and Sunday. As of 2016 China Southern Airlines will have flights from Guangzhou China to Phu Quoc and 1 weekly chartered flight from Sweden to Phu Quoc via TUI Nordic.
With regarding to traveling by sea, you are required to complete details on sea operators to and from the island, schedules, costs and international cruising options.
You can get to Phu Quoc by combination of bus and ferry from either Cambodia or Ho Chi Minh city. The routes are well established and you will find it quite comfortable.

When you get off from the buses at Ha Tien city and port or Rach Gia city & port, you will have only 2 ferry companies that serve the island travel service. They are Superdong, which is the fast ferry/hydrofoil and Thanh Thoi, which is the slow ferry and is used to transport cars and heavy machinery. If you are traveling by motorbike, you can bring it on board the fast ferry for an additional fee.

column1: 10187,"[:en]Tips for traveling in Vietnam: during the trip[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align: justify;"">

column2: Tips for traveling in Vietnam  will mention about currency, credit cards and ATMs, money chargers, Internet, SIM cards, local SIM, foods,drinks and taxi that tourists should note down for a great trip in Vietnam
Currency

Vietnamese people use the Vietnamese papers not coins. The official currency in Vietnam is the Dong, Vietnam Dong (VND), which is non-convertible currency. American dollars are widely accepted in larger stores and supermarkets.
Credit cards and ATMs

There are ATMs mostly in everywhere, especially in cities with a number of international banks in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh city.  Credit cards or MasterCard are accepted in many hotels, restaurants and large stores.  ATMs are easy to find in cities and towns, but often the maximum amount dispensed from local banks is quite low.  You can withdraw higher amounts from ANZ and HSBC, saving you from paying multiple withdrawal fees. ANZ customers pay no withdrawal fees when they use ANZ ATMs in Vietnam. Commonwealth Bank has a number of branches and ATMs in Ho Chi Minh City.
Money changers

You'll have no trouble finding exchange stores in tourist areas and cities. Most banks, including the government-run Vietcombank can also exchange your Australian dollars for Vietnamese dong. You should avoid changing too much money at the airport as you're unlikely to get a good exchange rate.
Internet

Internet access is so cheap. Cafes and hotels offer free Wi-Fi in the cities and tourist areas. Hotspots include KFC, Lotteria, Jollibee, Pizza Hut offer free Wi-Fi too. Internet speeds and service can be patchy in some places, and the entire country sometimes experiences drop outs (which can happen when sharks chew on the undersea cable providing internet to Vietnam!).
SIM Card

You should be able to get phone and 3G coverage in most areas of Vietnam. Make sure that you buy your SIM card through an established service provider in Vietnam. You can consider buying Tourist SIM right at the airport. The most –used brand there is Viettel, Mobifone and Vinaphone.
Local SIM

You should use a Vietnamese pre-paid SIM card  to access data and phone call while you're in the country and you can easily find it from some travel agents, travel shops, post offices and online. They're particularly good if you're planning on visiting a number of countries and you want to keep the same number.  Please notice that your phone will need to be unlocked to accept a SIM from another network.
Foods

Vietnamese food is fragrant, delicious and healthy. You wil find a delicious food on offer in most streets of big cities. You can enjoy street food tour to experience a lot of great foods of Hanoi. Pho and Banh mi are often refered to as the soul of the nation that people can eat very day whenever they feel hungry. It is served in most Vietnamese restaurants and street food vendors. You will experience great foods in the street, which is the best food in the country.
Drinks
You should avoid drinking tap water and choose only good mineral water kept away from the sun. it is best to buy bottle of water with popular label brand names such as La Vie.
Taxi
You can take reliable taxi companies in the South, Mai Linh and Vinasun. Some more reliable taxi brand can be Taxi group, Mai Linh group in the North.
More information about Tips for traveling in Vietnam, please contact us via vietnamvisavoa.com or hotline: +84.941279289

column1: 10192,"[:en]Vietnam culture and custom-Vietnam travel guide[:vi]Vietnam culture and custom-Vietnam travel guide[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: For most Western travelers coming to Vietnam, they must feel Vietnam culture and custom difference. There tips about dining, tipping and culture etiquette below will help you avoid culture shock and enjoy your trip.
Dining etiquette
<li style=""text-align:justify"">

column3: It is polite gesture to take all dishes using both hands. When passing something to another person, use both your hands together or just your right hand, too.

column2: <li style=""text-align:justify"">

column3: If you are invited to a Vietnamese home, you should bring fruits, sweets, flowers. You should not give handkerchiefs, yellow or black flowers or chrysanthemums.

column2: <li style=""text-align:justify"">

column3: You should place your chopsticks on the designated chopsticks holder when taking a break to drink or to speak.

column2: <li style=""text-align:justify"">

column3: You should try every dish that is served before eating more for your favorite ones to show your respect for the host.

column2: <li style=""text-align:justify"">

column3: When eating something together, you should not consume only one thing and you should leave some for others, which is considered as courtesy.

column2: <li style=""text-align:justify"">

column3: You should try to finish the food put on your plate. This shows respect for the cook and is not wasteful.

column2: <li style=""text-align:justify"">

column3: You also should not turn down any food offerings despite being full. To maintain politeness, inform the host that you are full prior to being offered another dish.

column2: Tipping
Tipping is a personal matter and travelers are encouraged to tip any service they feel is appropriate . Normally, travelers tend to tip for restaurants, bellboy , guides and drivers.
Cultural differences
<li style=""text-align:justify"">

column3: It is important that these differences about culture are respected. Some of few important customs of the Vietnamese people travelers should notice well.

column2: <li style=""text-align:justify"">

column3: It is rude to show any frustrations or annoyances by shouting or becoming abusive

column2: <li style=""text-align:justify"">

column3: Pointing your finger is not good as well. You should use gesture using your whole hand instead.

column2: <li style=""text-align:justify"">

column3: Tourists always should remember to wear shorts to the knees and cover shoulders when visiting any pagodas and temples. It is also regulations that both locals and tourists always remove your shoes or even raincoat when entering a temple or even at somebody’s home.

column2: Please contact us at vietnamvisavoa.com or hotline: +84.941279289 for further information about Vietnam culture and custom.

column1: 10201,"[:en] Top 5 best shopping centers in Hanoi[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: Hanoi is not only famous for its history and its culture but it is also an ideal place for doing shopping. Shopping in Hanoi is well-known for its bustling markets in every single street in Hanoi and you can do it all on foot with many streets dedicated to specific trades. Vietnamvisavoa.com is going to take you to 5 best shopping centers in Hanoi as listed below:
1. Dong Xuan Market

This is the wholesaler of Hanoi city with a wide range of products for sale over four floors. It is located along the Night Market with Soviet-style building. You can easily find out everything here at cheap price but acceptable quality. It is Hanoi’s largest indoor market, offering a wide range of goods such as: souvenirs, accessories, clothings, even electric appliances. It is very noisy with a rough-and-style building, surrounded on all sides by merchant shops and stalls. It is also very remarkable for the heaven of street foods in Dong Xuan alley. It is opened daily from 6:00 a.m to 19:00p.m. It is great place for visitting and go shopping, especially experience the local lifestyle.
2. Hang Da Shopping Mall

It is a modern, air conditioned building which has a collection of fashion stalls with cheap clothes, shoes, bags and accessories. It is a worthy place to pick up one-off clothing items including skirts, dresses and coats which are in perfect condition. It is the place that you can take a break and buy some freshly cooked Vietnamese snacks. The clothes on offer come in all sizes because the most of the clothes here are imported from across the globe. This is also a good place to buy traditional long Vietnamese dresses Ao Dai, local artwork and handicrafts for instance: ceramics, silk, lacquer and paintings.
3. Trang Tien Plaza

Trang Tien Plaza is a luxurious shopping mall in Ha Noi. It is in the heart of Hanoi which is just five –minute walk from Hoan Kiem Lake and French Quarter. Most Hanoi’s rich and famous people come to shop for luxury items and international designer goods with leading fashion brands such as: Cartier, Burberry, Ermenegildo Zegna and Louis Vuitton on the ground floor, electronics and home furnishings spread out over the second and third floors. Some excellent international restaurants with a variety of regional cuisine and plenty of fast food chains are available on the fifth floor of the shopping mall.
4. Hanoi Night Market

The night market is held every Friday, Saturday and Sunday night. It is very busy, bustling gathering of roadside stalls and local food vendors that brings a huge number of locals and tourists here. The market stretches from Hang Dao street and run North to the edge of Dong Xuan Market. People just walk in and find various stuffs under decorative lights. You can easily buy inexpensive T-shirts, handicrafts, accessories, shoes, sunglasses and souvenirs in Hanoi weekend night market.
5. Vincom Mega Mall Royal city

Vincom Mega Mall Royal city is situated in Thanh Xuan district and boats a massive underground shopping mall of 800 retail outlets, a massive hypermarket, as well as numerous outdoor and indoor recreational facilities. It features an elegant all-white interior design and with indoor ice-skating rink, cinema, food, beverage streets with more than 200 International and local restaurants. Vincom Mega Mall Royal City is also home to the biggest rainforest-themed indoor water park in Southeast Asia. Visitors of all ages can enjoy six complexes of water slides, wave pools, concave sliding tubes, and water games.

Further information about Top 5 best shopping centers in Hanoi, please contact us at support@vietnamvisavoa.com and do not forget to submit your visa request online at http://vietnamvisavoa.com/apply-online/ to get into Vietnam and enjoy your shopping passion.

column2: Many expats are looking for good renting apartment cost in Ho Chi Minh city and they should search information about the avarage price and good real estate in this big city. Here are some advice that you can consider.

Ho Chi Minh city is much bigger than Hanoi with  better living conditions for expats. With new apartment buildings being constructed at a breakneck pace, the housing market here has plenty of openings, and most are fully furnished.

The first thing is that you can search information about places to stay in Ho Chi Minh City  on many property agents. There are several ways to find rental listings in Ho Chi Minh City then. An agent can show you houses and help you negotiate your lease with a landlord well.

To get the best cost for renting apartment, you should search information about index of cost of living in one good one that I would like to recommend: Numbeo.com.  According to the information that I have searched via this web the renting apartment cost for one apartment with 1 bedroom in city centre will be around $600 on average. If you consider the better one outside the centre, you should consider the price about $350. Then you can easily find good real estate agency online with high standards and you can give the smart decision for renting. It should be the real estate agent that staff there can speak English, and have a great website that shows rental listings with pictures for you.
The more popular districts of Ho Chi Minh City 1 and 7 will be expected to start around  $600. If you would love to get cheaper price, however, District 8, might be considerably cheaper.
