Transit Vietnam visa

Do I need a Vietnam visa if I just transit in Vietnam? Vietnam does not require any transit visas for transit purpose as long as you do not get out of transit area at Vietnam airports like most countries in the world, except for the US, UK and Canada.
You do not need a transit visa Vietnam as long as you are waiting for another international flight within 24 hours and staying inside within the transit /international departure area.

If your flights are on the same carrier then you will be given both boarding passes when you check in for the first flight. If not then, you need to take the first stop by the Transfer Desk and they will issue your next boarding passes before entering the departure area.

You can spend time sleeping at the airport or do some shopping as they do have some shops and restaurants, but they are not really spacious and there are a lot of passengers. There might have loungers available and like most airports admission depending on carrier and fare class. International airports such as Hanoi/ Noi Bai Airport and Danang International Airport are quite small and are not really suitable places for a light-sleeper. Therefore if you have an over-night transit, you might want to exit the airport and stay at a nearby hotel. In those cases, you will need a normal single entry visa.
You can apply online with vietnamvisavoa.com to get Vietnam visa letter online easily and quickly rather than getting visa done at Vietnam Embassy/ Consulate of Vietnam.
Further information about Transit Vietnam visa, feel free to contact us via support@vietnamvisavoa.com or hotline: +84.941279289

column1: 10222,"[:en]How to travel between Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh city ?[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh are the two biggest cities in Vietnam. There are many ways to travel between Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh city: by trains, flights or sleeping bus.
1. Travelling by flight between Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh city

With regard to traveling by flights, there are 383 flights a week from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh city. The most popular airline flying from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh is Vietnam Airlines. The average flight time from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh city is 2 hours 4 minutes with the distance of 721 miles (1161Km) and around 53 euro for the cheapest return price from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh city. (according to skyscanner.net).

There are up to 30 flights departs from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh City from Monday to Sunday, operated by Vietnam Airlines or Jetstar Pacific. The earliest flight is at 6AM and latest flight is at 9:50 PM. One way flight takes between 1 hour 50 minutes and 2 hours to arrive. Fare depends upon the time you book your flight: the earlier the cheaper.

Vietnam Airlines ticket for Hanoi - Ho Chi Minh City route is about $120 US for one way. Jetstar Pacific Airways ticket for Hanoi - Ho Chi Minh City flights is about $100 one way (in sales season, it can drop to as low as $50 one way).

There are up to 30 flights depart from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh City from Monday to Sunday, operated by Vietnam Airlines or Jetstar Pacific. The earliest flight is at 6AM and latest flight is at 9:50PM. One way flight takes between 1 hour 50 minutes and 2 hours to arrive. Ticket cost depends on when you book: the earlier the cheaper.
Vietnam Airlines currently operates 14 daily HAN to SGN flights with the average price for one-way ticket for economy class is 68 USD (non-taxes) while business class is about 181 USD (non-taxes).
2. Travelling by train between Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh city

With regard to train, you can get tickets from the ticket booths at the city train stations - which is the cheapest way to buy one. Sometimes, buying the ticket off the counter can save you up to 30%.

The railway from Hanoi station to Ho Chi Minh (Saigon) station is 1726 kilometers. There are 4 trains including SE1, SE3, SE5 and SE7 on this route. They depart every day and takes about 34 hours from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh city. Seats include: the hard seat, the soft seat, the hard berth (6 berths) and the soft berth (4 berths), called cabin. Each cabin is equipped with air-conditioner and comfortable seat/berth
Ticket fare: $70 (Soft Seat)  - $90 (Hard berth) - $99 (Soft berth) - Agent fare
3. Travelling by bus between Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh city

For sleeper bus, you can travel overland with a low budget and it is a great way to travel around the country. It is one part of open bus tour system. It will save your money but very little route and take long time, you might want to vary your route or change mode of transport. You can check http://www.sleeperbusvietnam.com/ for every destination you go through. It might be ok for parts of the country but for most people, it is said that the train is much better and it is not more expensive. More important, you will get beautiful view from the trains.
Further information about travel from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh, please contact us via vietnamvisavoa.com or support@vietnamvisavoa.com
Let's apply online to visit Vietnam now!

There are so many travellers would ask How to travel around Vietnam?, The answer is that you can take flight, train, car, local buses, motorbike, bicycle, boat or cyclos depending on distance of traveling and your budget.

Planes in Vietnam offer reasonable fare and there are frequent flights to main hubs. Flights with some popular airlines are Vietnam Airline, Vietjet, Jetstar Pacific and Air Mekong. To avoid unexpected situations, you should book them in advance and then spend time on setting up plans to visit Vietnam. It is adviced to take flights from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh and in return in about 2 hours to save time.

Vietnam’s train system is quite good than it was used tobe. It is not all that cheap but comfortable and excited with many interesting and fun way to travel. If you travel in high season or in traditional New Year holiday, book soon as much as possible. Taking train from Hanoi to Sapa is also so much popular and would be an unforgetful experience for travellers. Check more in details: https://vietnam-railway.com/\ .

Rental cars for travelling in some places of Vietnam is quite popular as well. Most people take self-transport or take motorbike to some moutainous places of interest such as Moc Chau, Ha Giang, Mai Chau etc. This kind of traveling around Vietnam is quite popular for expats as well as locals.

Buses are available for traveling in short distance. It is a a kind of saving cost but it takes times to wait for buses at the bus stop. It is usually used widely for back packers or expats living in Vietnam. Search for routes carefully before you get on the bus.

Taxis is a good choice for those who stay in all major cities. Taxis is widely used by both locals and foreigners at a moderate price around 10,000 VND/ km. It is very common to travel in the centre cities. If traveling far away, you'd better take coach or rental cars.
Xe om and cyclos have unfixed fares and you need to ask experience to bargain price well.
Further information about How to travel around Vietnam ?, please contact us via vietnamvisavoa.com or support@vietnamvisavoa.com
Let's apply online to visit Vietnam now!

column1: 10313,"[:en]Ideal itinerary in Vietnam for a week[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: Ideal itinerary for a week in Vietnam
What if you only have one week and you want to enjoy unforgettable memory in Vietnam?
Here is the suggestion for your 7-day holiday in Vietnam.
It is recommended for you to enjoy most famous places throughout Vietnam in three regions: the North, the South and the Central.  The trip will start from Hanoi and end in Ho Chi Minh city.
Day 1: Hanoi

Hanoi is the capital of Vietnam and you will arrive at the Noi Bai international airport. You should visit main attractions such as: Hoan Kiem Lake, the Old Quarter Hanoi, a city that exist its state from a hundred years back. You will get a deeply cultural and ancient experience.

You should not miss the Temple of Literature, which is the first national university of Vietnam and temple of Confucius. Do not forget  Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. You should visit Ho Chi Minh complex first in the morning and visit others stops in the afternoon. In the evening, it is ideal time to enjoy Hanoi street foods such as Pho, Banh mi, Bun cha etc. in the Old Quarter. After that you can take one-hour cyclo around the Old Quarter.
Day 2: Hanoi

In the morning, you should visit National Museum of Vietnamese History designed by a French architect. Then you can get back to the Hoan Kiem Lake and watch water puppet show at Thang Long Opera Theatre right besides the lake. In the afternoon, travel to Long Bien Bridge and West Lake to see the sunrise in one of the most beautiful streets of Hanoi.
Day 3: Ha Long Bay

It is the main tourist attraction in Northern Vietnam. It is recognized as the World Heritage site by UNESCO in 1994.  It is famous for its emerald waters punctuated with over 2000 colossal limestone islands as well as rain forests with breathtaking view, too.  You can take a full day tour of Ha Long Bay.
Day 4: Ninh Binh

You should take one day trip to Tam Coc, Ninh Binh. You will see a lot of beautiful caves with very peaceful roads and get relax on the ride with bicycle there. You will enjoy the spectacular scenery while gliding along the river among rice paddies and ranges of limestone mountains peaking up towers over you.
Day 5: Hoi An

Hoi AN is one of the most unique cities in Vietnam. The Old town is recognized by UNESCO as heritage site. The old architecture is superbly preserved and displayed. You can stroll along the Old town and explore the city by checking out the most famous bridge in Hoi An. The first stop is the historic Japanese covered brigde built by Japanese merchants when Hoi An was an important trading port.

You will feel amazed when enjoying street food in Hoi An and see the old colonial architecture from the old time and go shopping here. In the evening, let visiting the Lantern market and enjoy night entertainment. In fact, it is big centre for paper lantern manufacturers and merchants.
Day 6: Ho Chi Minh city

You should explore the major part in the history of the Vietnam War with French colonial architecture including Notre - Dame Basilica and the Saigon Central Post Office. You should not miss the War Remmants Museum which presents the chilling and horrific war relics. Ben Thanh market is a great place to enjoy local cuisine here. In the evening, you can enjoy the night by sitting at back packer streets  in Pham Ngu Lao, Bui Vien.....sipping some beer or coffee and chatting with funy friends.
Day 7: Cu Chi Tunnels and Mekong Delta

Cu Chi Tunnel is a must see destination as it is a great place which show you the network of connecting underground hand-dug tunnels that was once used by Viet Cong soldiers as hiding places, their base of operations and supply and communication routes, hospitals and military campaigns during the Vietnam War. Then you can trek the largest rice bowl of Vietnam. You can enjoy a drive through My Tho countryside and feast your eyes with the Delta’s coconut palms, fruit orchards and sugar-cane groves. Nothing is more attractive than the floating market here.
For further information about Ideal itinerary for a week in Vietnam, please contact us via support@vietnamvisavoa.com or hotline: +84.941279289
Cant wait to see Vietnam, start with getting Vietnam visa on arrival easily here

Vietnam main imported goods are machinery, transports and equipment and manufactured goods. Others include: chemicals, fuels, food and live animals and crude materials except fuels. Main import partners are China which accounts for 28 percent of the total imports and Korea for 15 percent. Others include Japan 9 percent, Taiwan 8 percent, Thailand 6 percent and Singapore 6 percent.

Vietnam imposes a tax on almost every type of product that is imported into the country. The tax rates range depending on the type of product like some kinds of consumer products and luxury goods, which are highly taxed while machinery, equipment, and raw materials, tend to receive lower taxes and even tax exemptions.
Imports are subject to import tax, Value-added tax (VAT) and, for certain goods, Special Consumption Tax (SCT).
Preferential tax rates apply to goods originating from countries, groups of countries, or territories, which apply the most favored nation treatment in their trade relations with Vietnam.
Special preferential tax rates apply to goods originating from countries, groups of countries, or territories, which apply special preferences on import tax to Vietnam.

Ordinary tax rates apply to goods originating from countries, groups of countries, or territories, which do not apply the most favored nation treatment of special preferences on import tax to Vietnam. Ordinary tax rates will be no more than 70 percent higher than the preferential tax rates specified by the government.

Imports in Vietnam decreased to 14340 USD Million in July from 14742 USD Million in June of 2016. Imports in Vietnam averaged 5534.87 USD Million from 1990 until 2016, reaching an all time high of 14938 USD Million in May of 2015 and a record low of 740 USD Million in February of 1999, reported by the General Statistics Office of Vietnam.
See more information about What to import into Vietnam via our website: vietnamvisavoa.com or here or email support@vietnamvisavoa.com

column1: 10395,"[:en]Best expat living areas in Hanoi ?[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: If you ask about the best expat living areas in Hanoi, there are lots of places for expats in main districts of inner city, while the quite popular areas for expats community in Hanoi are the areas with fully-furnished house, security and services such as Tay Ho District, Ba Dinh District, even in Ciputra in West Lake area.
Many foreigners come to Vietnam for work and soon recognize the favorable living environment is in Hanoi, then decide to find out the good place to stay longer here.
The best location to you depends upon your work place as well, and the budget you would like to put in a home or an apartment and the home which you will send your children into.
The two most popular expat living areas in Hanoi are Ciputra and West Lake (Tay Ho, Quang An).

Ciputra is one of the most favourite expat living areas in Hanoi that is closed and guarded residential areas with several International schools and lots of green space. It is by the far the most preferred area by expats. However, people living here will be very likely expats or Vietnamese families with high income. Also, its drawback is that the area has quite limited choice of restaurants and supermarket and is a bit far from the centre and everything seems to be very expensive. Some people like this area because it is quiet and peaceful to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city, while others find bored with creational activities here. Furthermore, it is obvious that cost for living here should be considered, especially for not high budget.

Another favorite area is in Quang An, Xuan Dieu area. This area is not closed to the centre but there are many different choices to stay: condo, house, villa, etc. Service is better with many restaurants for foreigners. The location is closer to the center than from Ciputra. However, security might not be as good as Ciputra because you will live in a regular residential area. But security is rarely a big problem in Hanoi.

Many expat living areas in Hanoi will meet the demand of foreigners from low-end to high-end living conditions. You should ask the price form estate agents in Hanoi for the deal by seeing good reviews from https://www.tripadvisor.com

For further information about expat living areas in Hanoi, please contact us via support@vietnamvisavoa.com or hotline: +84.941279289 or read more information here: http://vietnamvisavoa.com/danh-muc/useful-information/living-in-vietnam/

column1: 10400,"[:en]Overview of business activities in Vietnam [:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: Business activities in Vietnam was evaluated by statistics that the economy has grown over 5% per cent each year (source: World Bank, GDP growth, annual %, Dec 2014),  the growth domestic product (GDP) per capita of US$1911 in 2013 (source: World Bank, GDP per capita, Dec 2014) and the poverty rate decreased to 17 % in 2012 (source: World Bank, WDI, Poverty rates at national poverty lines, Dec 2014).
Economic reforms concluded in WTO accession in 2007 has further boosted international trade and foreign investment.

More specially, Vietnamese export figures have been growing at double-digit rates for several years, reaching US$132 billion in 2013. Trade flows from Australia to Vietnam started decreasing in 2012 for the first time in 10 years, from US$2.1 billion in 2011 to US$1.6 billion in 2013. Goods worth US$3.5 billion were imported into Australia from Vietnam in 2013 (source: UN, Comtrade Database, Dec 2014).

In 2014, imports rose 12.1%, reaching US$148 billion, most of which are materials and machinery needed for export. China continued to be Vietnam's largest import partner, with US$43.7 billion. The ASEAN is second with US$23.1 billion, South Korea is third, Japan is fourth and the EU is the fifth largest import partner of Vietnam.

Australia ranks in the top 15 of Vietnam’s most important trade partners in both directions of trade (source: UN, Comtrade Database, Dec 2014). Australia’s main exports to Vietnam are timber products, plastic materials, oil and steel scraps and Australia mainly imports crude oil, telephones and components, seafood and cashew nuts from Vietnam (source: The Voice of Vietnam, Vietnam posts record trade surplus with Australia, 31 Aug 2014).

The country was reclassified by the World Bank as a lower middle-income country in 2009. However, labour productivity is improving as the economy moves increasingly from agriculture and industry into services. The country’s score from 2013 to 2014 in the World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index has increased markedly, ranking Vietnam as the 68th most competitive economy, out of 144 in its latest edition. However, inadequate infrastructure, macroeconomic instability, skills shortages, restricted land ownership rights, a troubled banking sector, corruption and dominant state owned enterprises (SOE) are challenges that still need to be tackled.
For further information about business activities in Vietnam, please contact us via support@vietnamvisavoa.com or hotline: +84941279289

column1: 10426,"[:en]One year Vietnam visa for US citizens[:]","[:en]<h2 style=""text-align:justify"">

column2: News release about one year Vietnam visa for US citizens

12 month multiple entries Vietnam visa for the US passport holder came into effect on August 25, 2016. US citizens now would be able to apply for a 1 year multiple entries visa for Vietnam. No matter how long you plan to stay in Vietnam. "All Visa applications of US citizens will be issued for 1 year multiple entries Visa."
All American passport holders enter into Vietnam with any purposes as tourist, business, visiting relatives, Investor ... will just get 01 year multiples entries visa.
How to get one year Vietnam visa for US citizens ?

Every time you enter into Vietnam, you can stay continously upto 3 months. If you stay longer than 3 months without leaving the country, you have to get a visa extension as usual or you have to leave the country and come back with another 3 months.

Firstly, you have to apply for a visa approval letter as normally at Vietnamvisavoa.com. Then, you will obtain this visa at Vietnam airports, Vietnamese embassies, Moc Bai border etc depending on your request. If you stay inside the country you have to go out and process this visa at the Vietnamese airports, Vietnamese embassies, Moc Bai border because it is impossible to change from your current visa into one year visa.
Apply online here to get Vietnam visa on arrival !

column1: 10590,"[:en]How to get Vietnam visa run at Moc Bai border?[:]","[:en]

column2: How to get Vietnam visa run at Moc Bai border ?

There is the truth that many tourists want to stay in Vietnam longer than 3 months however getting visa extension inside of Vietnam is relatively expensive. It costs you more than $ 300 US for 3 months multiple visa, in comparison with getting a new visa, it is many times more expensive. If you want to get your visa extended in a cost saving way, it is recommended to do Vietnam visa run at Moc Bai border. Let us show you in details how this procedure work.
1. Get Vietnam visa approval letter which is specially used for Moc Bai border entry.

You must choose a trust worthy travel agency to get an Original Vietnamese visa approval letter. Please note with them that you must get visa stamped visa at Moc Bai border to avoid getting wrong visa letter type.
Service fee: Depend upond your visa duration, either 1 month, 3 months, 6 months or 1 year visa, you pay different service fee for travel agency.
2. Go to Moc Bai border
Option 1: Take a public bus No.703 at Bus station in Park 23/9 (at the corner of Pham Ngu Lao and Cong Quynh street, opposite to Thai Binh Market.
Frequency: 30 minutes/1 bus. And just go to Moc Bai Border
Price: 1,5$/1 way
This option is recommended if you just want get the visa run at Moc Bai border.
Option 2: Book any bus at any office at Pham Ngu Lao street (Sapaco is popular one). You can buy it yourself. Be noted that this bus go to Phnompenh
Frequency: depend on the bus company you choose, and it go to Phnompenh.
Price: 10-12$/1way
This option is good for going inside Cambodia and back to Vietnam.
3. How does visa run work at Moc Bai border?
You do exit Vietnam and get the Exit stamp on your passport at Vietnam Immigration Dept at Moc Bai border (Vietnam side)
You enter Cambodia with an Entrance stamp on your passport at Cambodia Immigration Dept at Bavet border (Cambodia side)
Cambodia visa: You will process on the spot and Cambodia visa fee is 35$
Depending upon your wish, you can leave Cambodia right away or stay in Cambodia for a holiday. Then you do the exit procedure with exit stamp on your passport and leave Cambodia.

You go back to Moc Bai border, fill in the entry visa form, and present the original letter, original passport, photos that you prepared, and pay for the stamp fee, get a new Vietnam visa stamped on your passport. The whole process may take around 15-20 minutes without hassle or trouble.
Stamping fee:
Single entry: 25$ for 1 month or 3 month
Multiple entries: 50$ for 1 month and  3 months, 95$ for 6 months, 135$ for 1 year.
Now you could take the same bus, get back to Vietnam and stay there till your new visa expires.

Vietnam visa extension and renewal

When you are staying in Vietnam and your visa is about to expire, you will need to extend or renew the visa. You will be able to stay in Vietnam longer without leaving Vietnam when your visa expires. When you need to extend and when you need to renew the visa?
1. Vietnam visa extension

Visa Extension means that you will have new staying duration permission in Vietnam. With visa extension, you only can stay in Vietnam without exiting Vietnam during your extended visa.This means you must apply for a new visa if you wish to come back Vietnam after leaving.
In order to apply for visa extension, your current visa has to meet some requirements of  Vietnam Immigration Department as below:
- Your current visa type has to be correspondent to your staying extending requirement.
- One more month extension: If your current visa is 1 month single/ multiple, 3 month single/ multiple, you can extend visa for 1 month more
- Three more month extension: If your current visa is 3 month single/multiple, you can extend visa for 3 month more.
2. Vietnam visa renewal

Visa renewal means that you are granted a new visa stamp and visa sticker on your passport with the new duration.The staying length is valid maximum in 3 months. Visa renewal is applied for someone who:
- Entered Vietnam with visa exemption.
- Has current visa is not correspondent to your staying extending requirement.
If you would like to upgrade your current visa from 1 month to 3 month, you have to renew 3 month single/multiple entry
If you would like to upgrade your current visa from single entry to multiple entry, you have to renew the visa.
3. Procedure to extend/renew
In order to get your Vietnam visa extension or visa renewal, please send information to our email: vietnamvisavoa@gmail.com with:
Passport copy
Current visa copy
Immigration stamp
Latest date of entry
Your current address in Vietnam
Basing on above information, we are going to provide you with further information.
Price: Will be charged depend upon your current visa type...etc, roughly $80 US- $350 US
Processing time:
From 5 to 7 working days once the original passport is sent to Vietnam Immigration
For any other information, feel free to contact us at any time at: +84969255515

Teaching English overseas could be a once in a life time experience in any country, and Vietnam is not an exception. If you are considering Vietnam for travelling, why not consider teaching English in Vietnam as your future career or even just a temporary job that helps you deal with your expense while being abroad? Do not miss information below which help you know what to expect when you teach English in Vietnam.
1.    Is there any requirement for teaching English in Vietnam?
The answer is perhaps both yes and no.

In general, a four-year college degree in any subject is required for a would-be English teacher in Vietnam and a TEFL certificate (Teaching English as a Foreign Language) is preferred. TEFL certificate courses are available in both Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, each course lasts about 5 days and costing about $1000. However, it does not mean that you could not get a good job without such certificates.
2.    Must I know Vietnamese?

Knowing Vietnamese is not a requirement as there are Vietnamese teaching assistants in most classes. Nevertheless, knowing Vietnamese will help you to interact with not only students in class but to communicate with locals easily.
3.    How much can I earn by teaching English in Vietnam?

There is no fixed salary. It all depends upon your ability and where you work but the expected salary is between $1000 and $2000/ month. In comparison with local’s salary, this amount is their big dream. With this income, you can get a decent rented apartment with much of budget for food and saving. You are going to have a good and easy life here.
4.    Where and whom will I be teaching?

Formal Education Institutions: Most expatriate English teachers choose private schools and English centers as their workplaces. When it comes to private schools, most classes are at basic level, or English for specific purposes such as English for business.

Working at an international school, on the other hand, generally require a college degree (in any subject) and a TEFL certificate or the equivalent. Experience is also required sometimes and such schools typically recruit overseas rather than locally to guarantee their teaching quality. Salary and other benefits make the job deserving.

Language Schools: Language centers in Vietnam recently have appeared as mushrooms after the rains as the desire to improve English proficiency as a job requirement is overwhelming. Almost all centers focus on training students to achieve high scores in international language tests such as: TOEFL, IELTS, and TOEIC. In these centers, salary is good and the schedule is quite flexible. The quality of these centers are varied, depend upon the tuition fees that students must pay. Among the most prestigious centers are ACET, British Council, Language Link, and Apollo.

Private Tutoring: There is private tutoring, which is preferred by most inexperienced English speaking teachers. There is a huge number of potential learners and it is easy to find them through your expat network. Most of the students are the children of expatriates whose parents maybe English speakers who are too busy to teach their children. Posting notices at expatriates’ housing complexes is one of the easiest ways to find your students.
5.    Working hours per week

Normally, full-time trainers will be required to teach 40 hours/week, of which real teaching hours inside class are from 18 -20 hours /week, and the rest of time will be spent for curriculum designing, class preparation, test marking, essay editing. Part-time trainers can work for 11-12 hours/week and take care of at least three classes per week.
6.    How to find teaching jobs in Vietnam
Community forum such as The New Hanoians or job ads website such as VietnamWork is a great place to search for job opportunities.
7.    Visa requirement

As you are working in Vietnam as English teacher, you will be required to have a work visa. Nevertheless, for short term teaching, people prefer to take a business visa which lasts from 1 month up to 1 year. Most employers will be responsible for assisting you with visa extension or arranging a work permit though some will ask you to do that yourself so check with them first.

column1: 10673,"[:en]Top tips for getting around Ho Chi Minh City easily[:]","[:en]

column2: Top tips for getting around Ho Chi Minh City easily

Ho Chi Minh, the biggest and most dynamic city in Vietnam which attracts millions of local people and foreigners each year. How is it possible to get around Ho Chi Minh City comfortably and economically?
1. From Ho Chi Minh/ Tan Son Nhat airport to downtown?

Tan Son Nhat International Airport is just 20 minutes away from the city center. Travelers can take either taxi or bus from the airport to the center. Bus 152 will take you from there to Ben Thanh market.
2. Top tips for getting around Ho Chi Minh City?

There are plenty of choices for getting around the city. For taxi, take most reliable brands: Vinasun or Mai Linh, both with green color. Need something cheaper? There are so many taxi motorbike which is called XE OM in Vietnamese. You should show the driver the map or the address of the place that you are going there. More convenient and more reliable, you had better take Uber or Grab. The best saving option is to take public bus which is just 7,000 VND for 1 ticket
3. Travel to other places?

Bus station is just opposite Ben Thanh market in District No.1, you can take bus to visit the Mekong Delta from Mien Tay or Mien Dong bus stations.  Even if you go to other destinations of the country, you can take bus from Mien Dong station. What is more, bus to Tay Ninh can be caught at Ben Thanh bus station.
Popular bus numbers  in Ben Thanh bus station:
Cho Lon station: Bus #1, 56
Mien Dong station: Bus#26
Mien Tay station: Bus#2
Tay Ninh: Bus#702
They also have the sleeper buses with two levels of bunk beds stacked neatly in three rows.

For more information about departure from bus station from Mien Dong, please check www.benxemiendong.com.vn  and http://bxmt.com.vn from Mien Tay bus station. You even can take the tourist bus between Ho Chi Minh and Phnom Penh which is just 6 hours.

Airfare is relatively cheap and there are many routes from Ho Chi Minh to other destinations both domestic and international. Such familiar carriers are: Vietnam Airlines, Vietjet, Jetstar. During Tet holiday the rates are higher.  Be sure to triple check your baggage weight.
For any other information related to travelling around of Vietnam, do contact us right at: +84969255515.

column1: 10680,"[:en]Shopping in Hanoi- what to buy in Hanoi city ?[:]","[:en]

column2: Hanoi, the one thousand year old capital of Vietnam. When coming to Hanoi as a tourist, Hanoi offers you a wide variety of items from authentic silk,ethnic minority souvenir to wooden products.

It is true that the majority of souvenirs and crafts in Hanoi are readily available in numerous shops in the Old Quarter which is in the center of nearby Hoan Kiem Lake. If you are looking for special local stuffs to buy when travelling to this city, do not miss the list below:
1. Silk and Embroidery:

Vietnamese people are famous for being hard working and skilful. Then do not miss authentic traditional silk when visiting Vietnam. There are some differences in the way locals make silk in each region of Vietnam but Van Phuc village in Hanoi has been well known for making the best silk in the country. You can buy different type of silks from draw silk, print silk or patterned silk with national decorations as a unique gift for friends and relatives right in Van Phuc Village (10 km South West of Hanoi) or visit silk shops in Hang Gai, a commercial street in the Old Quarter.
2. Ethnic Minority Products:

Vietnam consists of 54 ethnic groups. The most dominant one is Kinh or Viet people who live in the flat areas of Vietnam: Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh and other 53 groups are scattering mostly in the Northern mountainous region in Vietnam. Each group has its own culture, costume with distinctive designs. Nowadays, both handicrafts and clothes with unique decorations and special weaving from various ethnic groups are widely sold in souvenirs shops in touristic area like: Lao Cai, Sapa, even in Hanoi capital.
3. Handicrafts:

Handicrafts in Hanoi varies from lacquer ware, mother-of-pearl inlaid furniture, ceramics, sandalwood statuettes, water colours, oil paintings, prints and assorted antiques (real and imitation). Hang Gai, To Tich, Hang Khai and Cau Go Street are significant shopping destinations. The price ranges from 3-7 USD/ item. For better price, do shopping in night market which is on Saturday night and Sunday night along Hang Dao Street.
4.  Imitation Backpacks and Bags

Vietnam may be the place of manufacture for brand names: North Face and Crumpler, but what is sold at the Old Quarters of Hanoi are mainly poorly made imitations of the real thing. Remember that you get what you pay for. If buying an authentic backpack is not at the top of your list, you can get by with just any bags, in that case Hanoi is actually a very ideal place to get them.  A medium sized backpack with a North Face logo can cost as low as USD 20. Shops selling bags are mainly clustered around Hoan Kiem Lake and nearby water puppet theatre.
5. Shoes

Shoe shoppers will be in retail heaven with hundreds of shoe sellers lining Hang Dau Street. Western men may not find much over size nine but there is plenty of choice in women’s shoes. Most of the footwear consists of brand names made at Vietnamese factories that have been rejected as seconds, making them a great purchase with usually only a small imperfection. There are also plenty of fake reproduction bags where Hang Dau Street meets Lo Su.
Useful Tips:
- In most cases, you can negotiate the price off 10-40% from the quoted price. Nonetheless, please be noted that a vigilant bargain hunters are always polite and friendly with a ready smile.
- It is better to shop around the Old Quarter to collect the price and select your most-interested items since browsing does not necessarily mean buying.
Hanoi night market
Once you visit Hanoi at weekend, you should not miss Ha Noi night market, a great place for discovering Hanoi night life and do shopping around.
Where and when is Hanoi night market?

Hanoi night market is held every Friday, Saturday and Sunday night. Hanoi Weekend Night Market is a busy, bustling gathering of roadside stalls and local food vendors that attracts huge crowds of locals as well as tourists. The market runs through the Old Quarter from 6 p.m to 11 p.m, starting from Hang Dao Street and running north to the edge of Dong Xuan Market.

In the daytime, this is still the route for transportation and tourism, where Hanoi people and tourists can go into the center of Old Quarter. However at night, all of the vehicles and means of transportation are prohibited from getting in, this place is just used for the walking and selling. Hanoi night market is a located in the heart of the old quarter of Hanoi. Before, it was only a street for trading activities at night and take place spontaneously. Afterwards, Hanoi government has planned and officially recognized it as a night market in Hanoi.
What to do in Hanoi night market?

Each night market, with about 2,000 booths are displayed, mostly items of clothing: T-shirts, handicrafts, shoes, sunglasses, textiles, souvenirs for tourists are sold at inexpensive, reasonable price. You can also enjoy many snacks and Vietnamese dishes: bun thang (rice vermicelli soup with shredded chicken, fried egg, and pork), La Vong grilled fish, pho (noodle soup with beef or chicken), banh mi (Vietnamese sandwich), and bun cha (rice noodles served with grilled pork)…….On overall, the atmosphere is so lively and do not forget to do some bargaining with a friendly smile on your face.  Moreover, pedestrian streets and historical sites within the area are illuminated with decorative lights, making this a popular spot for travelling photographers.

Hanoi Weekend Night Market also displays cultural performances, where locals in traditional costumes play traditional Vietnamese music as well as classical tunes. Even though Hanoi is a safe and peaceful please, during the busy night market, do keep an eye on your belongings.

column1: 10687,"[:en]Best things to do in Hanoi Old Quarter[:]","[:en]

column2: Best things to do in Hanoi Old Quarter

Hanoi, Vietnam’s capital lies in the North of the country and is one of the country’s top tourist hot spots. It offers French-colonial architecture, a rich food culture and a long history (the city celebrated its millennium in 2010) the most well-known area is the the Old Quarter located in Hoan Kiem district. This is considered the city’s business hub and main tourist destination. This guide of the best things to do in Hanoi Old Quarter is ideal for travelers looking to experience the rare sense of timelessness that seems to sum up this area of the city – you can still see glimpses of previous generations despite the modernization that is going on relentlessly. Located on the Northern end of Hoan Kiem Lake, Hanoi Old Quarter’s most popular attractions comprise mostly quaint Buddhist shrines, street markets, and traditional Vietnamese arts.
1. Thang Long Water Puppet Theatre

Thang Long Water Puppet Theatre, located along Dinh Tien Hoang Street, comprises 17 short sketches using traditional puppets within a one-hour performance. A Vietnamese orchestra accompanies each story, with musicians playing traditional operatic songs using drums, wooden bells, horns, bamboo flutes and cymbals. Tickets sell out well in advance so it’s worth booking yours as soon as you arrive in town.
Location: 57B, Dinh Tien Hoang Street, Hoan Kiem District, Hanoi
Price Range: VND 100,000
2. Hoan Kiem Lake & Ngoc Son Temple

Hoan Kiem Lake is where you can find locals jogging, enjoying coffee, ice creams, taking wedding photographs, playing music and even practicing Tai Chi and line dancing. This peaceful lake surrounds Ngoc Son Temple, an 18th century pagoda lying on a small island that’s accessible via an ornate red wooden bridge. Inside the temple are several altars dedicated to military leader Tran Hung Dao, large bronze bust, some ancient artefacts including ceramics, and a preserved specimen of a giant turtle found in the lake weighing 250kg. Tickets to Ngoc Son Temple can be purchased at a booth in front of the bridge.
Opening Hours: Daily 07:30 – 17:30 (Ngoc Son Temple)
Location: Hanoi Old Quarter
Price Range: VND 20,000 to enter the temple
3. Hang Da Market

Located in the intersection of Ha Trung, Duong Thanh and hang Dieu Street, the Hang Da Market is a popular hang-out among the locals and the tourists visiting Hanoi. This market is also located very close to many other tourist attractions like Ho Chi Minh Museum, Saint Joseph Cathedral, and Vietnam Women’s Museum.

In the past, Hang Da market sold mainly leather products, and hence it was called “Hang Da” (leather market). Nowadays, the old market has been upgraded into a small shopping mall that would offer you variety of products, ranging from food, beverage to clothes, jewelries, and even an entertainment area for children. By the way, do not forget that bargaining is really expected when you do shopping at Hang Da market. As a rule, start at around 50% of the starting price but do not accept any lower than 25%.
Opening times: Daily from 6.00AM to 21.00PM
4. Saint Joseph Cathedral of Hanoi

Saint Joseph Cathedral of Hanoi is known as the oldest Roman Catholic Church in the city. Prior to the construction of the cathedral in 1886, the French occupation demolished Bao Thien Pagoda, an important Vietnamese temple that was built during the Ly Dynasty. Saint Joseph Cathedral of Hanoi was inspired by Notre Dame de Paris, boasting a neo-Gothic architectural style, twin bell towers, intricately-designed altar, and colorful paintings and stained-glass windows from France. Surrounded by plenty of trees and flowers, a statue of Mother Maria is also set within the courtyard in front of the cathedral. After visiting the Cathedral, don’t forget to take a break, try out some cool lemon tea right on the pavement in front of the Cathedral.
Opening Hours: Daily 08:00 – 17:00
Location: 40 Nha Chung Street, Hoan Kiem District, Hanoi
5. Maison Centrale Hanoi (Hoa Lo Prison)

Maison Centrale in Hanoi, also known as Hoa Lo Prison and the ‘Hanoi Hilton’ housed Vietnamese revolutionaries and American POW during the Vietnam War. The fortress was once a vast colonial-style prison, most of which was torn down in the 1990s. Nowadays, you will find the small Southern section resting alongside a hotel and office complex. The prison is still a popular tourist attraction for those on the war history trail. Official records claim inmates numbered in their hundreds although it was not unknown for up to 2,000 prisoners to be crammed into a space reserved for 600 inmates
6. Hanoi Weekend Night Market

The Weekend Night Market in Hanoi is a busy, bustling gathering of stalls and vendors that brings crowds in droves. Taking place every Friday, Saturday and Sunday from 18:00, the market runs through the Old Quarter, starting from Hang Dao Street and running north to the edge of Dong Xuan Market. The fashion items on sale won’t turn many heads and the souvenirs can all be found in the surrounding stalls, but there it is a fun environment and the endless food vendors have interesting and exotic things to try. Bartering is normal here and, as with all busy markets, be aware of your belongings. Get more information about Hanoi Weekend Night Market
Should you have any doubts or need any further instruction, just contact our support team at:
Phone: +84969.255.515
Email: Vietnamvisavoa@gmail.com

column1: 10701,"[:en]News on Vietnam visa exemption updated on 30th June, 2017[:]","[:en]

column2: News on Vietnam visa exemption updated on 30<sup>th</sup> June, 2017
You are wondering whether you are exempted from Vietnam visa or not? And does Vietnam visa exemption for Western European continue to be extended after 30th June 2107?

Together with issuance of E-visa launched since January of this year, the Prime Minister of Vietnam officially approved extension of visa waiver program for visitors from: the United Kingdom, Germany, France, Italy and Spain. This policy was piloted in July 2015 and has been extended in two consecutive years until July 2018 as a part of boosting Vietnam tourism industry.
Yet, being citizens of countries listed above, you are just completely qualified to get visa exempted if:
- Staying no more than 15 days in Vietnam
- Travelling with passport having at least 6 month validity since your actual arrival date
Special note: For return trip, you to have wait 30 days since your latest exit of Vietnam

For citizens have not been granted under this policy and for those who are exempted from Vietnam visa but would like to stay in Vietnam longer than 15 days, visa on arrival is an easy and simple way to get Vietnam visa, please visit our website to apply: http://vietnamvisavoa.com/

column1: 10708,"[:en]Vietnam business visa - how to get it ?[:vi]Vietnam business visa - how to get it ?[:]","[:en]

column2: Vietnam business visa which is categorized as DN, LV, DT, is granted to those entering Vietnam for business purpose. This business visa type can be valid from 1 month up to 1 year either single or multiple entry. Except businessmen in Vietnam visa exception list, all other businessmen must apply for a Vietnam business visa in order to do business activities inside of Vietnam.
How to apply for Vietnam business visa?
There are two options for businessmen to get Vietnam business visa:
<li>

column3: Applying for Vietnam business visa at Vietnam Embassy/Consulate

column2: <li>

column3: Applying for Vietnam business visa online to get visa on arrival

column2: Depend upon how easier it is for applicant, they can either choose Embassy or online service. As a business person, one usually does have short noticed business trip abroad, therefore online application is much preferable. If you have enough time, getting business visa at Vietnam Embassy is also fine. However, whenever business visa is requested at Vietnam Embassies/Consulates, the applicants are required a letter of entry clearance from the Ministry of Public Security obtained by your business partner in Vietnam. Get further details about Vietnam visa business process as below:
1. Applying for Vietnam business visa at Vietnam Embassy/Consulate
The requirements of business visa may vary from place to place but most of them will require the following documents:
Original passport: Your passport must be valid for at least 06 months according to requirements of airlines. If there is no blank page on the passport, a loose-leaf visa will be issued.

Application form: The form is available for downloading at official website of embassies. You can also get it directly at their office. The form must be completed, signed and attached with 01 passport photo.

Letter of entry clearance: The business partner in Vietnam will support you get this letter. You just need to provide them with your passport details, type of visa, proposed date of entry and name of the Vietnamese embassy/consulate you wish to collect the visa from. If you are planning to visit Vietnam either for holiday or for business, it is highly recommended to get must know information about Vietnam.
Socialist Republic of Vietnam
Population: 90.5 million
Capital City: Hanoi (6.5 million)
People: 54 ethnic minorities
Language: Vietnamese
Currency: Vietnam Dong (VND)
Time Zone: GMT +7 Hours
International Dialing Code: +84

Vietnam is a small yet majestic country, it has many things to offer travelers. It creates an exciting trip with the mixture of adventure and culture. The country’s captivating natural wonders span from the mountainous North and the fertile plains of the Mekong Delta, to the spectacular coastline of central Vietnam and the magnificent Ha Long Bay. With an intriguing history spanning back over 4,000 years, including occupations from Chinese and French, the country’s architecture and cuisine is a fascinating testament to cultural diversity.
General Information
Passport and visa
Passports should be valid for six months from the date of entry into Vietnam. It is recommended to make a photocopy of your passport and keep it separated in case your original passport get lost.

Visa: Except those who are exempted from Vietnam visa, other visitors must apply for a Vietnam visa. Depending upon how long they are staying in Vietnam and how they are getting to Vietnam, they either can take Vietnam visa at Vietnam Embassy or get Vietnam visa on arrival. A tourist visa would last either 30 days or 90 days which is valid for single or multiple entries.
Currency

The official currency in Vietnam is the Dong (VND) which is a non-convertible currency. American dollars are widely accepted in larger stores and supermarkets as well as in touristic cities: Hanoi, Ha Long, Ho Chi Minh. Visa and MasterCard are accepted in most of hotels, restaurants and large stores. ATMs are widely available throughout the country, and there are a number of international banks in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City. You can exchange money quite easily at airports, banks, even in the hotels, shops….
Phones & Internet service

The Vietnamese postal service is reliable and there are also courier services widely available. For postcards, do not put postcards into letter boxes. Instead of that, you should put them to your hotel to post or go to a post office by yourself.

Telephone connections to the rest of the world are widely available, however they are not cheap. A Vietnamese SIM card is a less expensive way of calling other countries, however your phone will need to be unlocked in order for it to work. For example, 200,000VND worth of Viettel credit ($10) can last for up to 45 minutes to the UK.
Internet access is available in all most hotels and WiFi is free in most coffee shops in developed areas.
Traffic & Transportation

The traffic in Vietnam is busy and slow. It may look like chaos but don’t be frightened to cross the road. Simply make your way shaking your whole hand at waist height. You’ll soon see other people doing the same.
Taxis are a popular way of getting around the cities but make sure you use a reputable company such as Mai Linh, VinaSun. On average, it costs half a dollars for 1 km length.
If you are in a developed area, a cyclo is a fun mean of transport and should cost no more than 100,000 VND per journey.
Motorbike taxis: Motorbike is the most popular mean of transportations in Vietnam however, travelling by unlicensed motorbike is not safe and it is not recommended.
Weather
Vietnam has a diverse climate that varies significantly from region to region:
The North (Hanoi to Sapa)
April to October: Temperatures between 30-35°C with occasional bursts of heavy rain.
December to March: Temperatures between 15-25°C. February and March can be damp with drizzle and overcast skies.
The Centre (Hue to Nha Trang)
Nha Trang: Sunshine all year round apart from November and December when the area has heavy rain.
Dalat: cooler than the coastal area, particularly from November to March.
Da Nang and Hue: typhoons from mid-October to mid-December
The South (Ho Chi Minh City to Phan Thiet)
May to October: hot and wet
November to April: hot and humid

column1: 10720,"[:en] How to transfer money oversea from Vietnam ?[:]","[:en]

column2: How to transfer money oversea from Vietnam ?

There are more and more foreigners are living and working in Vietnam. Many of them need to transfer their income back to their homeland. Then what are the best way to transfer money oversea from Vietnam ?

In general, there are2 popular ways of sending money out of Vietnam: One by the 3rd party underground, and it is a illigal way so you have to take risk from both the polices and the 3rd party which makes your transfer. The good is it is easy as its risk, you dont need any papers but your money, and sometimes it´s very cheap. Any way, I do not recommend you to take this risk unless you know the third party so well.
[caption id=""attachment_10721"" align=""aligncenter"" width=""275""]Send money abroad from Vietnam[/caption]

The 2nd way is, of course legal way, always related to the bank no matter what method you take to transfer: Bank to bank, or via Moneygram, or via Westernunion, or transfer to you Paypal account. The price is various depends upon the amount, the destination, the currency and the method you choose, but not much and you will be consultanted by the bank officer to meet your require about time and cost. It will be very easy and quick, so dont worry. Only one thing you need to worry is showing evidence to prove that amount of money is legal and belongs to you, so you have the right to put it in your account or directly transfer to any country you want to.
If money stays in your account already, that´s legal incomes and you have your right  to decide what to do with that money.

If you bring cash in, please show documents related, such as if they come from your salary, so we need your work permit paper, labour contract, payroll slips, your passport; if they come from your business, you need your passport, work permit paper, business lisence, financial reports and tax reports; If you bring them from your country, show the custom papers; and so on. In any cases, just prove your right about those money.

There are some diffirences if the sender is Vietnamese. Vietnamese just need to show up the legal purpose using money outside of Vietnam in many cases such as tuition fees, living cost for students or nuclear family members support, hospital expenses. But if Vietnamese received a big amount of money from hesitate or as a gift, they must be present more papers and variety from every cases abide by the law. In that case, you should contact with the bank then they will give you advice to complete paper documents.
Banks recomended for transfer money oversea from Vietnam are: Vietcombank, HSBC

column1: 10733,"[:en]Why to set up your business in Ho Chi Minh ?[:]","[:en]

column2: Investors, when they think of doing business in Vietnam, they often mention Ho Chi Minh. Why to set up your business in Ho Chi Minh ?

Ho Chi Minh City, the dynamic city located in the South of Vietnam, is considered as Vietnam’s economic centre. During the long history of foundation and development, the city’s economy proves itself as constant growth and it keeps motivating the development of Vietnam.

Ho Chi Minh is regarded as a potential investment environment for not only domestic investors but also it attracts foreign investors. The investment through establishing companies and conducting business activities in Ho Chi Minh city certainly promises to achieve multiple benefits. Following facts will show you why Ho Chi Minh attracts start up business.
1.    Huge Population

There are more than 10 million people are lving in Ho Chi Minh who are earning a higher average income than any other part of the country.  Consumer retail has found Ho Chi Minh City as an attractive market for investment in retail shops, malls, introducing quality consumer goods to the local. Ho Chi Minh City is also famous for  well – qualified, abundant and young human resources. The percentage of labor source holding postgraduate degree is also increasing year by year and most of them tend to stay in the city after holding degrees. Ho Chi Minh City is also home to more than 80 universities and colleges, vocational schools with over 400,000 students providing an abundant trained work force.
[caption id=""attachment_10734"" align=""aligncenter"" width=""300""]set-up-business-in-ho-chi-minh[/caption]
2.    Adequate infrastructure

Ho Chi Minh City offers adequate infrastructure such as: Sai Gon port systems, deep seaport access from Vung Tau port systems, Tan Son Nhat international airport, and possible Long Thanh international airport project, Saigon railway station, the expressways, etc, connecting the city to neighbouring countries in the region: Singapore, Cambodia… and other part of the world. Tan Son Nhat Airport is the largest airport in the country with the capacity to accommodate 20 million people a year. From Tan Son Nhat Airport, there are 50 routes to other countries all over the world such as China, Japan, Korea, Singapore, European countries, etc.  Through setting up factories in industrial zones, processing zones, local and international manufacturing companies could take advantage of high quality labor resources at reasonable cost and move the finished goods to final destinations in US, EU with reasonable lead-time and expenses.  Consequently, the city has become leading industrial city of Vietnam, contributing more than 30% industrial production, 30% GPD and 30% national income to the country’s total.
3.    Financial center

Ho Chi Minh City is also a financial center, which the biggest stock exchange is located.  Many corporations, and investment companies has chosen Ho Chi Minh City to set-up management and investment offices to search for opportunities,  conduct Merger and Acquisitions and other business transactions, to leverage the annual growth of the country at more than 6%.
4.    Simple administrative process

In addition to above benefits, the city government has been improving policies to support the removal of difficulties for foreign-invested enterprises investing in Vietnam  through fixing administrative procedures to shorten the administrative process, saving time for investors, offering “one-stop” mechanism at the main state agencies.

For any other information or instruction about setting up business in Ho Chi Minh, kindly contact us:Vietnamvisavoa.com/ +84969255515/support@vietnamvisavoa.com. It is most recommended to apply for a tourist visa, pay for a visit to Vietnam, learn about Ho Chi Minh to see if you are suitable for this place before you decide to invest here.
Best time to visit Sapa

Being first established by French in 1922 as a hill station during the war, now Sapa is firmly one of the most favorite destinations for domestic and international tourists. Sapa not only owns a special and unique terrain but also boasts a very distinctly sub-tropical climate which is rarely experienced in a tropical country like Vietnam. Located in the northern mountainous area, Sapa is endowed with favorable conditions for the growth of a versatile fauna and flora

Sapa has different beauties in each season however tourists must choose the right time to witness the most spectacular scenes in Sapa. In this post, we are going to tell you what is the best time to visit Sapa.
General information

Thanks to its high altitude, Sapa is an ideal location for summer retreat during the overheated summer time and the scarcely populated town also has pretty fresh air. The climate of Sapa is highly seasonal, with a subtropical climate in the summer and a temperate climate during the winter.

The average temperature for Sapa town is 15.4ºC, with a maximum of 29.4ºC and a minimum of 1ºC. The warmest months are July and August, and the coldest months are December and January. While trips can be enjoyed year-round, the winters in Sapa get cold, with some fog and drizzle, and snow falls in some years on the highest peaks.

The four seasons are distinctly seen in Sapa when Nature changes her costume. Spring is bright with significant fruits: pears, peaches, apricots and plum flowers. Summer comes blooming with pancies, dahlias, sun-flowers and numerous temperate fruits. Autumn is the time for perfume mushrooms, woodears and plenty of specious medical plants… The sky is the vividly brightened with golden sun-rays and playful white clouds which seem to land on the ground, over the heads of people or on tops of trees. In winter, fog filled the space, making the landscapes look more mystery and attractive.

Sapa also experiences a marked wet season from May to September, with the heaviest rainfall occurring in July and August. The weather is notorious for changing frequently and quickly. Visitor to Sapa in summer can feel the climate of four seasons in one day. In the morning and afternoon, it is cool like the weather of spring and autumn. At noon, it is as sunny and cloudless as the weather of summer. And it is cold in the evening. With no advance warning of a thunderstorm short and heavy rains may come at noon on any summer day. Subsequently, a rainbow appears, transforming Sapa into a magic land.
Best time to visit Sapa
September to December – best time for sight-seeing

In these months, the weather is perfect and suitable for sight-seeing, photo-taking and camping. This is the summer season in Sapa when the sky is absolutely clear and blue, which makes the landscapes most amazing. The sun shines through hundreds of mountains create huge shadows in combination with vibrant landscapes and deep blue sky; all that visual effects come together to make Sapa much more outstanding. The weather is warmer in these months, but there’re some summer rains to refresh the atmosphere. In general, this is one of the best time to visit Sapa.
March to May – another great time to visit Sapa
Sapa is known as paradise for trekking and it is best to do trekking during this time as this is spring season when plants grow and flowers blossom.

column1: 10747,"[:en]What to do when the passport is lost in Vietnam ?[:]","[:en]

column2: While travelling in Vietnam, your passport is lost because of some  popular reasons like : robbery, by being careless, you dropped it somewhere, losing the passport in washing machine… you feel depressed.What you must do to get a new passport and also to get a Vietnam visa for not staying in Vietnam illegally ?
Step 1. Report to the closest Vietnamese police office where your passport is lost.

When you realize your passport is lost, the first thing you must do is  to report to Vietnamese police office as soon as possible. You must claim where, when and how your passport is lost or stolen. After finishing the report with detailed information about that, you will receive the confirmed document on your lost passport issue from the police. With this document, it will be easy to get emergency passport from your Embassy or Consulate-General in the next step.
Step 2. Apply for a new passport at your Embassy or Consulate
The next step you must follow is get to your closest Embassy or consulate and apply for a new passport to replace the old one.
Required documents for renewing passport:
<li>

column3: Application for a passport renewal

column2: <li>

column3: 2 passport sized photos

column2: <li>

column3: A copy of passport

column2: When you go to your Embassy or Consulate-General, they will help and show you procedures to apply for the new passport. The new passport may be issued within two working days and you are required to pay an additional fee to have the new passport replaced with the lost one.
Step 3. Get a replacement Vietnam visa

After your new passport has been issued, your Embassy or Consulate-General will give you a letter to the Vietnamese Immigration Department, which requests their assistance to issue a replacement visa in your new passport. Vietnamese authorities will not permit you to leave Vietnam until your replacement visa is issued. A fee will be payable to the relevant Immigration Department.
Documents needed to submit at Vietnam Immigration to process the exit visa:
<li>

column3: Your new passport

column2: <li>

column3: Passport photo

column2: <li>

column3: The report on the loss of exit and entry visa (certified by Local Police Department)

column2: <li>

column3: The diplomatic note of yours Embassy or Consulate

column2: <li>

column3: Your air tickets

column2: Vietnam Immigration address:
Vietnamese Immigration Department in Hanoi: 44-46 Tran Phu, Ba Dinh, Ha Noi
Vietnamese Immigration Department in Da Nang: No. 7 Tran Quy Cap street, Da Nang city.
Vietnamese Immigration Department in Ho Chi Minh city: No. 161 Nguyen Du, Ben Thanh Ward, District 1, Ho Chi Minh City.
Special advices about passport while travelling:
<li>

column3: You should make at least two copies your passport while travelling. This will help  when you apply for a new passport and to apply for a new visa.

column2: <li>

column3: When you get  a new passport, the passport number is not the same as the old, please check your airline booking and your visa for other countries as soon as the new passport is issued. The old visas in the lost passports are just: LOST

column1: 10758,"[:en]How to get TT Vietnam visa and VR Vietnam visa ?[:]","[:en]

column2: 1- Who can get TT  and VR Vietnam visa ?
- Visa TT is issued to foreigners who:
+ Are parents, spouse, children under 18 years of age of the foreigners issued with LV1, LV2, ĐT, NN1, NN2, DH, PV1, LĐ visas.
+ Are parents, spouse, and children of Vietnamese citizens.
The duration of TT visa is not longer than 12 months.
- Visa VR is issued to people who come to visit their relatives (grand parents, parents, spouse, and children) in Vietnam.
The duration of VR visa is not longer than 6 months.
2- Procedures to get Vietnam visa TT or Vietnam VR visa:
2.1- Apply online for a TT or VR Vietnam visa approval letter:

Before entering Vietnam, applicants must apply for TT/ VR Vietnam visa approval letter which is granted by the Immigration Department which can be done within 1 week. To get TT/VR visa type, do contact our support team at:  hotline: +84969255515/ Email: vietnamvisavisa@gmail.com for detail.
Note:

- The most required document for visa TT or visa VR is legal written document which proves the relationship between the invited individual and the applicants. That document can be: Certificate of birth, Certificate of marriage, Certificate of family relationship.
2.2- Picking up TT/ VR visa to enter Vietnam:

Foreigners are normally granted to pick up Vietnam visa TT or visa VR either at overseas visa-issuing authority of Vietnam (Vietnam Embassy, Vietnam General Representative,…) or can pick up visa on arrival at Vietnam Int’l airports (Noi Bai airport- Ha Noi City, Da Nang airport- Da Nang City, Cam Ranh airport- Nha Trang City, Tan Son Nhat airport- Ho Chi Minh City).
3- TT/ VR Vietnam visa extension, visa renewal, apply for TT Temporary residence card:
3.1- Required documents:

Once foreigners are in Vietnam and they wish to extend their stay, they either can extend their current visa or apply for Temporary Residence Card which lasts for 3 years. To apply for Temporary residence card, you must submit these documents:
- Application form (will be done by us)
- Origin passport with valid TT or VR visa
- Foreigners’ police registration of residential stay in Vietnam
- Enclosed documents which prove legal status of invited organization as prescribed by Vietnam’s law.
3.2- Processing time:
Within 5-7 working days.
For any other information or further request, please feel free to contact us:
Hotline: +84969255515

Website: vietnamvisavoa.com

Hanoi is the capital of Socialist Republic of Vietnam which located in the Red River Delta, in the center of North Vietnam. Hanoi is a perfect blend of the exotic chic of old Asia and the dynamic face of new Asia, of Parisian grace and the Asian pace. Hanoi has such diversity- from the old quarter to the urban areas.
Where to visit?
<li>

column3: Hoan Kiem Lake: The symbol of Hanoi city

column2: <li>

column3: Ho Chi Minh Museum & Mausoleum – Ho Chi Minh is Vietnam’s leader and founder of the communist state.

column2: <li>

column3: Hoa Lo Prison – U.S. POWs named Hoa Lo “the Hanoi Hilton”

column2: <li>

column3: Dong Xuan Market – Hanoi’s oldest market is located in the Old Quarter.

column2: <li>

column3: Old Quarter – The Old Quarter’s 2,000-year-old streets are a web of shopping opportunities and cheap eateries.

column2: <li>

column3: Temple of Literature – Built in 1070, the Van Mieu temple is a great example of traditional Vietnamese architecture and is one of the oldest structures in the country

column2: <li>

column3: Museum of Ethnology – A multipurpose institution, serving as both a research facility and a public museum.

column2: <li>

column3: Water puppet theatre – Water Puppetry as an art form dates back over a millennium in Vietnam

column2: What to eat?

Being the centre of culture, Hanoi offers various types of foods come from different parts of Vietnam as well as the mixture food between Vietnam- France, Vietnam- China. Dont forget to try different types of tasty foods in Hanoi. Surely, you wont forget its unique taste.

column1: 10797,"[:en]10 fun facts about Vietnamese cuisine that you should not miss [:]","[:en]

column2: Vietnamese cuisine is considered amongst the healthiest in the world with the combination of fresh herbs, a lot of vegetables and seafood prepared with traditional cooking techniques that avoids frying and oils in their food. Again, there are specialities for Vietnamese but it becomes terrified dishes to foreigners. Let discover 10 facts about Vietnamese dishes.

1.     The Vietnamese believe in Three Kitchen Gods or Tao Quan, who live with and observe each family’s actions. They depart at the end of the Lunar Year to report their findings to Ngoc Hoan, The Jade Emperor.
2.     Their cuisine is well known for its balance of the five Asian elements; spicy, sour, bitter, salty and sweet.
3.     The principle of yin and yang is also applied in composing a meal, to provide contrasts in spiciness and temperature of the food.
4.    Tiet Canh is a traditional Vietnamese dish made from fresh animal blood.
5.    When cooking a pig, the entire animal is used including the innards.
6.     Snake wine, which is made by steeping whole snakes in rice wine for their venom or essence, is commonly drunk for health, vitality and restorative purposes.
7.    Vietnam’s street food culture is quite popular and considered by many to be one of the best in the world.
8.    Noodles or “pho” are the second most popular food in Vietnam, after boiled rice.
9.    They eat what most Westerners consider pets - dog meat
Vietnam is the second largest consumer of dog meat with nearly five million dogs being killed. Dog meat is believed to bring good fortune in Vietnamese culture.
10.     They have half-hatched eggs for breakfast
Balut, a developed bird embryo that is boiled and eaten from the shell, is a common Vietnamese breakfast.
So when you are travelling to Vietnam, do you like to try out all the special foods that they have in Vietnam?
For any tips about food you must try in Vietnam:
http://vietnamvisavoa.com/8-best-foods-in-hanoi/

column1: 10820,"[:en]Temporary residence registration for foreigners in Vietnam[:]","[:en]

column2: Many foreigners stay for quite a long time in Vietnam and do not register their stay until they are asked by police officer then pay expensive fine. These people again blame on the landlord and other agents for not reminding them to do temporary resident registration. According to Vietnamese law, foreigners must register their stay wherever they spend night(s) in Vietnam.
Gist:
<li>

column3: Long-term residents will need to reregister regularly

column2: <li>

column3: Registration is usually done through the owner of the property, who is usually held responsibility in cases of noncompliance unless the expat is clearly at fault.

column2: <li>

column3: Temporary residence books are kept to make a record of the length of time an expat has spent at a particular property, but the regulations and costs vary between wards.

column2: <li>

column3: Failure to register accommodation can incur a fine between 500,000 to 5,000,000 VND

column2: <li>

column3: In extreme circumstances, this may be seen as a failure to comply with the terms of your visa, which can be cancelled

column2: <li>

column3: You may elect to pass the responsibility of maintaining your registration on to an agent

column2: If you’re staying in Vietnam for more than just a few nights, registering your residential address is an issue that you’re going to have to pay attention to regularly.

According to Vietnamese immigration law, you’re obliged to comply with the regulations related to your accommodation by observing the duration of residence as stated in your approved visa application. Your initial temporary residence registration should have occurred when you arrived at the border gate and presented your passport. During your period of residing in Vietnam, however, you do need to report your residential address to the ward/local authorities via any property owners or landlords who allow you to stay the night at their premises. The law states:

Foreigners who stay overnight at the private houses of citizens shall have to personally or through house owners make a temporary residence declaration with the police offices of wards or communes where they temporarily reside. The ward or commune police offices will then be required to transfer the contents of temporary residence declarations by foreigners to the immigration bodies under the public security offices of the provinces or centrally run cities.
Laying Down the Law
According to Vietnamese law, there are a number of regulations that control and define the process of accommodation and registration of foreigners in Vietnam:
Regulation 24/1999/PL- UBTVQH10 on Entry, Exit, and Transit of Foreigners in Vietnam
Regulation 21/ NĐ_CP on the Process of Admitting Foreign Entry into Vietnam
Regulation 01/2012/TTLT/BCA-BNG updating the Process of Admitting Foreign Entry and Exit in Vietnam

Regulation 136/1999/QĐ- BTC on Fees Level for Entry, Exit, and Transit Process of Foreigners. Regulation 73/2010/NĐ-CP on Fine Levels for Violations against the Safety and Order of the City (of which the registration process for foreigners’ accommodation is included in part 20).
Together, they spell out the facts and processes of registering your accommodation over the long term.

The property owner will be the one in charge of registering all tenants domiciled within the property with local police. For expats renting accommodation with Vietnamese owners, these owners are the ones responsible for taking care of the paperwork (and subsequently for the fines, in case of late or no registration, unless the expat was clearly at fault (e.g. denying passports and documents needed for registration, etc). In practice, however, the expat is sometimes regarded as being at fault even when culpability is not clear, leaving little option but to pay the fine. It’s to your advantage, therefore, to proactively encourage your landlord to process your registration in a timely fashion.

For expats co-owning their properties with their Vietnamese spouses, they (or their Vietnamese spouses) are the ones responsible. Even when using an intermediary agent, all legal responsibilities lie with the expat (as there is no contract binding the agent and the government).
The level of local authority in charge of processing registration documents is the ward-level police department.
The required documents as stated by law and by the Central Police Department are:
Identity card / Passport / Permanent Residence Card
Temporary residence booklet with place of accommodation.
Typical residence book

The residence book is a document that may have no ideas to foreigners  however, all occupants of residential properties in Vietnam have a permanent residence book of their own, which serves to associate them with the administrative ward – in the event they move home, they will register a new residency book with their new local police station.

A temporary residence book associates you with a local jurisdiction for the period of your stay. This has to be first acquired with your local police office on the ward level. This kind of booklet is most often used by accommodation service providers or people housing their visiting relatives. In the case of expats, this booklet could be kept by the landlord or by the tenant. It is essentially a list of all temporary tenants in the building and the time and length of their stays.
Document form HK01 (acquired at ward-level local police station)
Document form HK02 (acquired at ward-level local police station)
The exact procedure and paperwork required to register differs from district to district, and even from ward to ward within the same district
[caption id=""attachment_10821"" align=""aligncenter"" width=""300""]Have you registered your accommodation in Vietnam yet ?[/caption]

Translated into real world practice, this means that the majority of documents will differ from place to place – both the temporary residence booklet itself and the application forms, with the booklet having the most significant variations between different police offices. It also means that procedures will be carried out differently in different districts.

The expository article in Tuoitre News reported that in some areas, documents and registration booklets are given out freely, while fees are charged for these items in others. Extra paperwork not required by law can be demanded in some areas, and the length of renewal or giving notice can (and will) vary significantly from place to place.

The application itself can be notoriously cumbersome in some districts and wards. There have been many reports from residence owners who have had to visit the local police station more than a dozen times without actually accomplishing anything, and the process itself can sometimes take months to complete.

Failure to register your accommodation with the local police may incur a fine from as little as 500,000 VND to as much as 5,000,000 VND, with the possibility of your visa/residence card being confiscated and forced deportation if the violation is serious enough.

You can elect to register yourself at the local police station, or you can grant authority for an agent to do so for you – useful if you are staying in Vietnam long-term and frequently changing your place of accommodation. The fee for this service is usually around $100.

Hopefully, the above information is useful for your stay in Vietnam and it is most recommended that you ask the landlord, the household to take care of the whole process for registering your stay on the first days of your arrival. Contact us at:
Phone: +84969255515
Email: Vietnamvisavoa@gmail.com
For any further enquiries!
Have a nice stay in Vietnam!

Vietnam is a developing country in South East Asia which attracts millions of foreigners each year for not just spending holiday but also this new economy opens up a variety of business oppotunity. Going along with the development in economy, Vietnamese Government also make Immigration to Vietnam become much easier than ever before.
1.    Does a Lebanese passport holder need visa for Vietnam?
Being a Lebanese citizen who takes regular passport must apply for Vietnam visa for permission to visit Vietnam for any purposes: tourism, business, family visit.
2.    How to get Vietnam visa in Lebanon?

Normally, a person can either apply for Vietnam visa at Vietnam Embassy or apply gor Vietnam visa on arrival. However, till now there is no Vietnam Embassy in Lebanon yet. Therefore, Lebanese passport holder and who reside in Lebanon can only get Vietnam visa on arrival
[caption id=""attachment_10827"" align=""aligncenter"" width=""300""]Vietnam visa for Lebanese passport holder [/caption]
2.1    Procedure to get Vietnam visa on arrival

+ Pay for service fee online:

Service fee is paid for us to get your Vietnam visa request approved at Vietnam Immigration. Service fee would change depend upon the nationality. As for Lebanese passport holder, you would need to pay $ 100 US service fee for 1 month single entry tourist visa.

+ Receive your Vietnam visa approval letter via email: After 3- 5 working days receiving your documents and payment for service fee, you will get your Vietnam visa approval letter sent to your email. You need to print out this document, take this document along with you to check in your flight.

Once you arrive in Vietnam airport, you would present the Vietnamese visa approval letter, Vietnamese visa application form, the passport and stamping fee to the officer. They will stamp a Vietnam visa on your passport.

Note: The validity of your visa will be indicated on the visa page. You should pay attention on the expiration date of your visa. You must leave Vietnam by that expiration or else you must do Vietnam visa extension for a longer stay in Vietnam.
